story:
Short Summary

You can ensure children and youth have access to safe and enriching afterschool and summer programs! 

The CA Afterschool and Summer Challenge is a one of a kind event that gathers hundreds in Sacramento to share compelling stories with legislators and advocate for vital programs for youth. Together we are the voice of young people, families and professionals across the state!  

Millions of young people every day have their lives positively impacted by afterschool and summer programs. Help ensure we can continue to change the lives of the young people. If we don’t do it, it won’t happen! 

We're turning to the community to raise $5,000 to support youth and adult advocates at the CA Afterschool and Summer Challenge! We believe that giving to something you believe in is empowering both for the individual and the organization. 

Together we can convene a strong, collective voice for children and youth that can increase funding for out-of-school time programs!


What We Need & What You Get

By giving to CalSAC you're making California a better place for children and youth!

The California School-Age Consortium (CalSAC) has worked to support and advance the out-of-school time (OST) field since 1982 by connecting professionals, enhancing competency, and building community. Our main goal is to elevate OST, to expand the social view that this field is crucial to our collective well being.

Every donation made will go toward direct event expenses that help ensure the CA Afterschool & Summer Challenge is free to the youth, families and staff that attend the event on May 11 & 12 from across the state. Expenses include but are not limited to meals, event materials, equipment and the event venue.  

Every donation makes a difference! Here are some of the ways your support helps us increase funding for out-of-school time programs: 

  • A donation of $10 makes it possible for someone to have a free box lunch. 
  • A donation of $50 makes it possible for someone to meet their legislative representative in person.
  • A donation of $100 makes it possible for someone to receive training before meeting with their legislative representative.

See a description of perks available in the bar to the right!


The Impact


This year's CA Afterschool & Summer Challenge is vital to securing long-term funding for out-of-school time programs. These programs hold the future of California by protecting our most important resource - our children. OST programs make a  significant difference:

  • $1 invested in afterschool programs saves taxpayers $9

  • Program participation increases school attendance, grades, test scores, and instills a sense of confidence and trust.

  • Quality programs can create opportunities for youth to feel recognized, gain a sense of responsibility, and peer mentorship

  • These programs inspire youth to explore a career, vocation, or college track

  • Children and youth discover of new skills, people, and ways of looking at life

Out-of-school time programs equip children and youth with the skills for school, work and life. Staff leading programs foster strong relationships and create safe environments that enable children to learn 21st century skills, develop socially and emotionally, and gain the skills employers seek most – critical thinking, collaboration and communication. You can learn more about the importance of a quality program here. 


Risks & Challenges

Without donations to help cover costs of the event, we would have to charge people to attend the event. Many of our participants are youth and young professionals who could not afford the cost of a fee to attend and with limited funding many programs would be deterred by an added cost. Without these participants to meet with their legislators we might lose out on funding for future generations of youth who need access to these vital programs.

This year we're facing an important crossroads in the determination of the future of the out-of-school time field. With statewide minimum wage increases, an increase in After School Education & Safety (ASES) Program funding is needed to help cover the rising cost of providing high-quality out-of-school time programs. 

A recent survey conducted by the Partnership for Children & Youth of nearly 600 respondents from 300 school districts in CA paints a grim picture. 

  • More than 75% of ASES-funded programs have found it is more difficult to retain high quality staff (unable to offer competitive pay) and more difficult to attract and recruit quality staff (unable to offer competitive pay). 
  • 75% of ASES-funded programs also believe it is necessary to reduce the number of enrichment activities offered to children. 
  • More than 60% of programs also cite a reduction in professional development for staff, an inability to meet the demand of students on waiting lists, and a negative impact on the ability to provide quality academic supports to students. 
  • Approximately 50% of respondents have had to reduce staff hours. 
  • Nearly 25% of programs are now serving fewer kids. 

We need a strong, collective voice at the CA Afterschool & Summer Challenge in support of SB645 to increase funding to programs. 

Senate Bill 645 would increase ASES funding by $54 million in 2015/16 to raise the funding formula to $8.50 per student/per day, and establish an annual cost of living adjustment beginning in the 2017/18 fiscal year. This funding correction would improve program providers’ ability to deliver engaging and effective expanded learning services to California students with the highest needs and fewest resources. Without increased funding many afterschool programs will be looking at cost-cutting measures putting thousands of jobs and children's safety at risk.

Now is the time to change this reality for children and youth! You can help by making a donation today. 


Other Ways You Can Help

1)  Share the word about this campaign with your colleagues, friends and loved ones through the sharing tools on this page!

2)  Ask your company or organization to sponsor the event, we love our partners and our work would not exist without them! Please contact Lexi Adsit, Communications & Development Coordinator at CalSAC to get more information on sponsorship opportunities. She can be reached at 510-444-4622 x109 or ladsit@calsac.org

story:
Be a part of the Roebling legacy and help The Roebling Museum educate future generations of leaders in industry, engineering, and technology!

Your support of this exciting Campaign will allow The Roebling Museum to recreate one of the world's greatest suspension bridges through the building of a “Golden Gate Tribute Bridge”, a scaled version of the San Francisco landmark that the Roebling's provided the cables for. The 80-foot model will serve to typify this 20th century marvel as interpreted and inspired by a metal sculptor who created its design, and use historic and donated American steel.

All funds raised through the Build-A-Bridge Campaign will ensure the museum’s ability to fulfill its mission to educate students from grade school to college, and the community at large, on the men and women whose innovations transformed the industrialized world and led to the construction of some of the world’s most recognizable icons.

This 80-foot structure will stand as a testament to the greatness of the engineers who continue to inspire us.  The project was designed by local craftsman Michael Waite, and will be built by Michael and his son Robert using historic Roebling steel wire.  With a target completion date near the end of May 2015, the bridge will serve as a permanent exhibit in the museum’s collection.

We want you to be a part of the legacy left by the Roeblings and the people who worked here.  The example they provided in the fields of engineering, technology, and industry serve as a key resource for the public, and continues to serve as an inspiration.

Our goal is not to simply build a tribute to one of the most well-known bridges in the world.  It’s to make sure that we don’t end there; to keep the dreams of great engineers and architects alive.  The Build-A-Bridge campaign is not only part of our past, it is a part of our future.

~ John Seitter, Roebling Museum Executive Director

story:
Short Summary

I have been teaching for 5 years and is currently an SDC teacher 4-6th grade at NEU @ Puesta Del Sol Elementary School in Victorville, CA. My students are amazing and my focus is on giving them the tools to empower themselves beyond their situations or the obstacles they may face. I am a tech coach, now known as "Tech Liberator" at my school, who holds weekly share/collaboration events via my site (http://goo.gl/ZXFQmB) and Google Classroom. I live for Twitter, my PLN (@crikeypotter), and global learning (http://goo.gl/Lup3gH). My classroom is a virtual one where students can learn anything, no matter the physical boundaries.

What We Need & What You Get

I need $600 for my hotel room and $350 for my round trip ticket to Miami for Miami Device. I also need flight and hotel for the Florida Education Technology Conference in January My trip will send me to one of the largest educational technology conferences in the nation and the impact on my students, staff and district will be immeasurable when I return with all of the latest info and connections I will make with new members of my PLN. 

Any company that sponsors me will get a mention at my session and I will promote your during the conference sessions and general keynotes I attend.

For any individual that sponsors me I will give you access to live Hangouts or Periscopes from the event. 

If I do not reach my goal, any funds collected will go towards future professional development conferences I attend. 

Thank you for your help

The Impact

To elevate teaching, you have to take it beyond your walls and into the world that we have created to inspire authentic experiences for our young ones. The brain craves authenticity and helping them learn on a global scale with things they have never experienced does this to elevate the learning world for students.

All of the info and connections I make will directly influence my tech coaching at my site and my district. I will find the latest innovations to help make a difference in the lives of my students. 

Risks & Challenges

  • The challenge I face is not getting to learn from some of the most innovative minds in education today.

  • Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help out monetarily please share and get the word out. Thanks

story:
AIAS Freedom by Design

AIAS Freedom by Design is a non-profit organization that utilizes the skills of Architecture students to radically improve the living conditions of disabled individuals within our local community. 


The KIND Project

Currently, we are working on The KIND Project in Old Medford, Long Island. The goal of this project is to rehabilitate the Excel Equestrian Therapy Farm which was severely damaged during hurricane Sandy. Due to these unsuitable living conditions, horses on this farm are facing severe illness and are in danger of dying. These horses are an integral part of the ongoing therapy at the farm, which is used to treat people with disabilities including children with Autism. 

With your potential donation, we will be that much closer to giving these horses a new home.

story:
Help Gold replace its stolen equipment

As you may know Gold Drum Corps' equipment truck was broken into early morning on Tuesday, July 14th. Several of the Corps' Trumpets were stolen, along with other miscellaneous equipment.

    The Corps recently purchased $70,000.00 worth of new equipment, including the stolen Horns. Gold is about to embark on its DCI Tour as part of our season that includes nearly 20 performances nearly 10,000 miles of travel.

story:
HARK, Inc. Presents

The Hope on the Horizon “Get Involved and Help” Tour


What?

·  A fifty state, nationwide university tour to spread the award-winning ALS adventure documentary Hope on the Horizon, and HARK’s mission to raise awareness and serve as a direct resource of support for families and patients of ALS

·  An educational and interactive motivational speaking event designed to inspire students to get involved in their community, and to show them what it feels like to touch the hearts of strangers by truly making a difference in this world

·  One university in each state will “adopt” an ALS family from the same state

·  Using their new fundraising skills and motivation gained from Josh and Kirk, each university will raise money towards a total minimum goal of $10,000 for their state’s family

HOW WE ARE CURRENTLY USING THE HOPE ON THE HORIZON ALS DOCUMENTARY


Over the course of the last year HARK has had 25 HOTH showings and public speaking engagements around the country.  19 of these were film festivals or non-fundraiser screenings, with the remaining 6 used to raise over $75,000 for the direct benefit of families with ALS.  Amongst our most successful was an event in Atlanta, GA.  The event saw the entire community rally together to support the Browns, a local ALS family and raised $15,000 to help ease the financial burden they faced as they battled the disease. 

Our support efforts have thus far included:

•  Providing financial assistance for general household items or equipment and supplies not covered by insurance

•  Paying travel expenses for ALS patients to visit family or attend an important family event

•  Holding ticketed showings of Hope on the Horizon to raise funds for a specific local ALS family (Featured on CBS news in Maine for one such event)

•  Hosted a free camp for children and grandchildren of ALS patients at Camp HLC with organizational assistance from Hope Loves Company

•  Funding for the Elaine Stewart Tyrell Memorial Scholarship at Centenary College

•  Funding for the Charlie Dourney Memorial Scholarship

•  Assisting ALS families with children during the holidays

A direct link to our documentary trailer:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FxeNjcqZWaA

A direct link to our latest television interview:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hPw3qe4c-70

A direct link to HARK’s website:

https://www.hark-als.org

Who?

Joshua Valentine


Joshua Valentine is a lifelong outdoor athlete, survival expert, guide, and adventure filmmaker.  He currently holds certifications as a Wilderness First Responder, ACA Recognized Whitewater Raft Guide, and in Avalanche Safety.  He continually completes backcountry endurance tests that astonish, such as the White Mountain and Adirondack Traverses, and a canoe trip from the highest source of the Hudson River to the Statue of Liberty.  Josh currently teaches wilderness survival through his private company, and for the Bear Grylls Survival Academy; and has worked as a safety guide on one of Bear’s TV shoots for NBC.  His dream to use his outdoor skills to affect positive change in the world began to come to light when he teamed with HARK to battle ALS by leading the expedition team to create the Hope on the Horizon film. Since then, he has volunteered on the HARK board, and traveled as a public speaking ambassador with the film all around the U.S., raising awareness and funds for families facing ALS.  When at home in New Jersey he is an active freelance writer, and is also in the final stages of publishing his first manuscript, detailing the incredible adventure in the White Mountains while making this film, and the life changing effects his ALS friends have had on his life.

Kirk Leslie


Kirk Leslie is a successful entrepreneur with multiple businesses launched throughout his career since graduating from Wilkes University with a B.B.A. in 2000.  This success has allowed Kirk to abide by his “live life to the fullest” motto, which has taken him on many adventures around the world.  When not seeking new business opportunities, or disappearing into the backcountry, Kirk can be found spending time with his wife Dena and two dogs, Bella and Scarlett.  His “work hard, play hard” lifestyle put Kirk in the perfect position to become part of Hope on the Horizon. This opportunity has been, and will continue to be, the most rewarding success in his life.  He has continued his outdoor accomplishments after the record setting traverse of the White Mountain 48-4000 footers in 2014, with a 2,200-mile Appalachian Trail Thru Hike from Georgia to Maine.  He currently resides in Colorado where he continues to ascend, not only mountains, but in his fulfilling life.

Why?

A brief summary of the current state of ALS awareness:

This past summer, the phenomenon that was the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge ran rampant across the U.S., raising over $115,000,000 and greatly increasing the public’s perception that ALS exists.

Outside the community, many now know that ALS exists, yet few still understand how devastating it actually is, or how inspiring the people are who are left to battle it each day.

A prime example of this was illustrated at a HOTH showing held at major New Jersey University.  When asked to raise their hands if they had participated in the Ice Bucket Challenge, the entire audience did so.  However, when the audience was asked to raise their hands if they knew what ALS actually was, and NOT A SINGLE person in the crowd raised their hands.

HARK’s Hope on the Horizon “Get Involved and Help” Tour is here to change that.  Over the course of the 2015, HARK will bring its mission of philanthropy, awareness, assistance, and social responsibility amongst our youth to each of the fifty states with the following ends in mind:

·  To eradicate the lack of awareness faced by the ALS community, by educating the upcoming generation about this disease and its effects; and exposing them directly to the experience and inspiration of helping an ALS family

·  To actively involve the students in the fight against ALS by calling them to action, to  “adopt” their university’s ALS family and raise $9,000 for the family’s direct benefit, exposing them to the tangible positive effects of philanthropy

·  To directly benefit fifty ALS patients and their families nationwide in two ways: financially, by donating $10,000 directly to them, and emotionally, by presenting them with the experience of working with a group of inspired young adults rallying for their cause

·  To propagate HARK’S mission of direct and active support for any and all ALS patients in need, and to build “Healthy, Active, Responsible Kids” by inspiring the upcoming generation to see beyond themselves to those in need, and to take action to better the world around them

·  To continue to unite other small, like-minded organizations together to share in one another’s missions, and to widen the reach of a nation wide network of resources and support for the ALS community

·  To use today’s generation’s knowledge and savvy of social media networking to optimize social media hits and exposure of the Hope on the Horizon documentary, and HARK’S overall mission

·  To raise a total of half a million dollars that will go directly to the benefit of the patients in need, and to set an example of transparency and adherence to mission for non-profits in the ALS community

·  To raise additional funds above and beyond the $10,000 per event to allow HARK to continue its mission of helping ALS families in need far into the future

·  To put HARK on the map of major ALS non profit organizations, allowing it to draw more attention to its cause, thus obtaining more funding to further its success

How?

 ·  HARK will use its National Leadership Program consultant to make contact with a professor and student at the head of each university’s leadership group, to assist in organizing the event and to connect the school with the state’s corresponding ALS family

·  HARK representatives Joshua Valentine and Kirk Leslie will travel to the university to screen the film and give a educational and motivational speech regarding their adventure making the film and their experience working within the ALS community to the gathered student body

·  The speech will conclude with the introduction of the ALS family to the audience, after which HARK will present a check for $1,000 to the family, and then call the students to action by raising the remaining $9,000

·  HARK will present a preset fundraising program, along with the knowledge to use it, and then ask that a minimum of 30 students come forward to raise a minimum of $300 each towards the overall $9,000 goal within a one month window

·  This initial 30 student group will have already been established and committed to the minimum by the student leadership program in advance of HARK’s arrival at the university, and this core group’s immediate response to HARK’s call to action will ideally inspire more students to follow their example and get involved themselves

·  This extra response from students along with participation from faculty, alumni, and donors present holds great potential to raise the total funds per each event to far beyond the $10,000 minimum goal

·  At the conclusion of the one month period, the total amount will be submitted to HARK upon the predetermined conclusion date, and HARK in turn will cut a check for an additional $9,000.00 to the university’s corresponding family

·  Each university “team” and their family can be found, and their progress tracked via the tour’s interactive website, displaying individual totals raised as well as a grand total raised towards the overall goal

·  The website will also feature a continuous feed of blogs, footage, and feedback from the students and families involved across the nation

·  Anything raised beyond the $10,000 goal for each family will go to HARK, to be used towards the future benefit of other families and patients with ALS, and to continue HARK’s mission of support indefinitely

How you can help:

  As HARK representatives, we respectfully request that you help donate to this unprecedented campaign to better the lives of countless Americans.  

·  Please support this groundbreaking effort to tackle the obstacles of this incurable and devastating disease while also inspiring a nation of young minds to take steps towards building a better world

·  Your tax deductible donation is necessary to make this tour possible

·  Your return on investment will be the tangible, measurable, positive effect that your generous contribution has allowed HARK to create from coast to coast

·  Please refer to the below budget outline; a HARK representative will be happy to break down and further explain in depth any portion of the included figures and will provide a detailed budget in spreadsheet form on request

Item

Cost

Payroll & Admin

$145,000.00

Airfare

$36,480.00

Rental Cars & Fuel

$10,800.00

Shipping T shirts and Fundraiser Packet

$10,000.00

Hotels

$14,400.00

Food

$12,500.00

T shirts

$12,500.00

Website, Design, Maintenance

$5,000.00

MISC

$2,500.00

Initial Donation to each Family

$50,000.00

Total Cost

$299,180.00
THE $101,281 FUND GOAL IS THE MINIMUM NEEDED FOR A TOUR START WITH 16 EVENTS, WITH THE TOTAL GOAL BEING $299,180 FOR ALL 50 EVENTS.

A Background on HARK, Inc.

HARK's Mission:

Hark is on a mission to share the real story of ALS and to provide a network of compassionate resources for families.

HARK’s Vision:

To change the way the world views ALS, and to create a courageous legacy of support for families.

What is ALS:

ALS stands for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, commonly known as Lou Gehrig’s Disease. 

ALS rapidly deteriorates the motor neurons in the brain and the spinal cord that allow voluntarily control of muscle movement. As the disease progresses the muscles begin to waste away or atrophy, causing increased muscle weakness, paralysis, and inability to swallow or breathe.  The patient’s mind remains fully cognizant throughout the entirety of this agonizing process, with death most commonly occurring within two years.

Scarce progress has been made in the area of research, diagnoses, or treatment.  There is presently no cure.

What is Hope on the Horizon:


An adventure documentary following two HARK representatives Joshua Valentine and Kirk Leslie’s successful mission to summit the 48 highest mountains in New Hampshire in a single, 25 day trip to raise awareness and support for ALS patients and families.  As it follows their journey, the film tells the story of the patients who have rallied behind this mission, and serves to educate the viewers about the disease, HARK’s mission, and the incredible struggle an ALS patient faces each day.  It concludes with a passionate call to action to “Get involved and help” by joining HARK’s mission to battle ALS.
story_txt:
HARK, Inc. Presents
The Hope on the
Horizon “Get Involved and Help” Tour
What?
· 
A fifty state, nationwide university tour to
spread the award-winning ALS adventure documentary Hope on the Horizon, and
HARK’s mission to raise awareness and serve as a direct resource of support for
families and patients of ALS
· 
An educational and interactive motivational
speaking event designed to inspire students to get involved in their community, and
to show them what it feels like to touch the hearts of strangers by truly
making a difference in this world
· 
One university in each state will “adopt” an ALS
family from the same state
·  Using their new fundraising skills and motivation gained from Josh and Kirk, each university will raise money towards a total minimum goal of $10,000 for their state’s family
HOW WE ARE CURRENTLY USING THE HOPE ON THE HORIZON ALS
DOCUMENTARY
Over the course of the last year HARK
has had 25 HOTH showings and public speaking engagements around the country. 
19 of these were film festivals or non-fundraiser screenings, with the
remaining 6 used to raise over $75,000 for the direct benefit of families with
ALS.  Amongst
our most successful was an event in Atlanta, GA.  The event saw the entire community rally
together to support the Browns, a local ALS family and raised $15,000 to help
ease the financial burden they faced as they battled the disease.  
Our support
efforts have thus far included:
•  Providing financial assistance for
general household items or equipment and supplies not covered by insurance
•  Paying travel expenses for ALS patients
to visit family or attend an important family event
•  Holding ticketed showings of Hope on the
Horizon to raise funds for a specific local ALS family (Featured on CBS news in
Maine for one such event)
•  Hosted a free camp for children and
grandchildren of ALS patients at Camp HLC with organizational assistance from
Hope Loves Company
•  Funding for the Elaine Stewart Tyrell Memorial
Scholarship at Centenary College
•  Funding for the Charlie Dourney Memorial
Scholarship 
•  Assisting ALS families with children
during the holidays
A direct link to our documentary trailer:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FxeNjcqZWaA
A direct link to our latest television interview:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hPw3qe4c-70
A direct link to HARK’s website:
https://www.hark-als.org

Who?Joshua ValentineJoshua Valentine is a lifelong outdoor athlete, survival expert, guide, and adventure filmmaker.  He currently holds certifications as a Wilderness First Responder, ACA Recognized Whitewater Raft Guide, and in Avalanche Safety.  He continually completes backcountry endurance tests that astonish, such as the White Mountain and Adirondack Traverses, and a canoe trip from the highest source of the Hudson River to the Statue of Liberty.  Josh currently teaches wilderness survival through his private company, and for the Bear Grylls Survival Academy; and has worked as a safety guide on one of Bear’s TV shoots for NBC.  His dream to use his outdoor skills to affect positive change in the world began to come to light when he teamed with HARK to battle ALS by leading the expedition team to create the Hope on the Horizon film. Since then, he has volunteered on the HARK board, and traveled as a public speaking ambassador with the film all around the U.S., raising awareness and funds for families facing ALS.  When at home in New Jersey he is an active freelance writer, and is also in the final stages of publishing his first manuscript, detailing the incredible adventure in the White Mountains while making this film, and the life changing effects his ALS friends have had on his life.Kirk LeslieKirk Leslie is a successful entrepreneur with multiple businesses launched throughout his career since graduating from Wilkes University with a B.B.A. in 2000.  This success has allowed Kirk to abide by his “live life to the fullest” motto, which has taken him on many adventures around the world.  When not seeking new business opportunities, or disappearing into the backcountry, Kirk can be found spending time with his wife Dena and two dogs, Bella and Scarlett.  His “work hard, play hard” lifestyle put Kirk in the perfect position to become part of Hope on the Horizon. This opportunity has been, and will continue to be, the most rewarding success in his life.  He has continued his outdoor accomplishments after the record setting traverse of the White Mountain 48-4000 footers in 2014, with a 2,200-mile Appalachian Trail Thru Hike from Georgia to Maine.  He currently resides in Colorado where he continues to ascend, not only mountains, but in his fulfilling life.Why?
A brief summary of the current state of ALS awareness:
This past summer, the phenomenon
that was the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge ran rampant across the U.S., raising over
$115,000,000 and greatly increasing the public’s perception that ALS exists.
Outside the community, many now
know that ALS exists, yet few still understand how devastating it actually is,
or how inspiring the people are who are left to battle it each day.
A prime example of this was illustrated at a HOTH showing held at major New Jersey University. 
When asked to raise their hands if they had participated in the Ice
Bucket Challenge, the entire audience did so. 
However, when the audience was asked to raise their hands if they knew
what ALS actually was, and NOT A SINGLE person in the crowd raised their hands.
HARK’s Hope on the Horizon “Get
Involved and Help” Tour is here to change that. 
Over the course of the 2015, HARK will bring its mission of
philanthropy, awareness, assistance, and social responsibility amongst our youth
to each of the fifty states with the following ends in mind:
· 
To eradicate the lack of awareness faced by the
ALS community, by educating the upcoming generation about this disease and its
effects; and exposing them directly to the experience and inspiration of
helping an ALS family
· 
To actively involve the students in the fight
against ALS by calling them to action, to 
“adopt” their university’s ALS family and raise $9,000 for the family’s
direct benefit, exposing them to the tangible positive effects of philanthropy
· 
To directly benefit fifty ALS patients and their
families nationwide in two ways: financially, by donating $10,000 directly to
them, and emotionally, by presenting them with the experience of working with a
group of inspired young adults rallying for their cause
· 
To propagate HARK’S mission of direct and active
support for any and all ALS patients in need, and to build “Healthy, Active,
Responsible Kids” by inspiring the upcoming generation to see beyond themselves
to those in need, and to take action to better the world around them
· 
To continue to unite other small, like-minded
organizations together to share in one another’s missions, and to widen the
reach of a nation wide network of resources and support for the ALS community
· 
To use today’s generation’s knowledge and savvy
of social media networking to optimize social media hits and exposure of the
Hope on the Horizon documentary, and HARK’S overall mission
· 
To raise a total of half a million dollars that
will go directly to the benefit of the patients in need, and to set an example
of transparency and adherence to mission for non-profits in the ALS community
· 
To raise additional funds above and beyond the
$10,000 per event to allow HARK to continue its mission of helping ALS families
in need far into the future
· 
To put HARK on the map of major ALS non profit
organizations, allowing it to draw more attention to its cause, thus obtaining
more funding to further its success
How?
 · 
HARK will use its National Leadership Program
consultant to make contact with a professor
and student at the head of each university’s leadership group, to assist in
organizing the event and to connect the school with the state’s corresponding
ALS family
· 
HARK representatives Joshua Valentine and Kirk
Leslie will travel to the university to screen the film and give a educational and motivational
speech regarding their adventure making the film and their experience working
within the ALS community to the gathered student body
· 
The speech will conclude with the introduction
of the ALS family to the audience, after which HARK will present a check for
$1,000 to the family, and then call the students to action by raising the
remaining $9,000
· 
HARK will present a preset fundraising program, along with the knowledge to use it, and then ask that a minimum of 30 students come forward to raise a
minimum of $300 each towards the overall $9,000 goal within a one month window
· 
This initial 30 student group will have already
been established and committed to the minimum by the student leadership program
in advance of HARK’s arrival at the university, and this core group’s immediate
response to HARK’s call to action will ideally inspire more students to follow
their example and get involved themselves
· 
This extra response from students along with
participation from faculty, alumni, and donors present holds great potential to
raise the total funds per each event to far beyond the $10,000 minimum goal
· 
At the conclusion of the one month period, the
total amount will be submitted to HARK upon the predetermined conclusion date, and
HARK in turn will cut a check for an additional $9,000.00 to the university’s
corresponding family
· 
Each university “team” and their family can be
found, and their progress tracked via the tour’s interactive website,
displaying individual totals raised as well as a grand total raised towards the
overall goal
· 
The website will also feature a continuous feed
of blogs, footage, and feedback from the students and families involved across
the nation
· 
Anything raised beyond the $10,000 goal for each
family will go to HARK, to be used towards the future benefit of other families
and patients with ALS, and to continue HARK’s mission of support indefinitely


How you can help:
  As HARK
representatives, we respectfully request that you help donate to this unprecedented campaign to better the lives of
countless Americans.  
· 
Please support this groundbreaking effort to
tackle the obstacles of this incurable and devastating disease while also
inspiring a nation of young minds to take steps towards building a better world
· 
Your tax deductible donation is necessary to
make this tour possible
· 
Your return on investment will be the tangible,
measurable, positive effect that your generous contribution has allowed HARK to
create from coast to coast
· 
Please refer to the below budget outline; a HARK
representative will be happy to break down and further explain in depth any
portion of the included figures and will provide a detailed budget in
spreadsheet form on request




Item


Cost




Payroll & Admin


$145,000.00




Airfare


$36,480.00




Rental Cars & Fuel


$10,800.00




Shipping T shirts and Fundraiser Packet


$10,000.00




Hotels


$14,400.00




Food


$12,500.00




T shirts 


$12,500.00




Website, Design, Maintenance


$5,000.00




MISC


$2,500.00




Initial Donation to each Family


$50,000.00




Total Cost


$299,180.00




THE $101,281 FUND GOAL IS THE MINIMUM NEEDED FOR A TOUR START WITH 16 EVENTS, WITH THE TOTAL GOAL BEING $299,180 FOR ALL 50 EVENTS.













A Background on HARK, Inc.

HARK's
  Mission:
Hark is on a mission to share the real story of ALS and to provide
  a network of compassionate resources for families.
HARK’s
  Vision:
To change
  the way the world views ALS, and to create a courageous legacy of support for
  families.
What is ALS:

ALS stands
  for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, commonly known as Lou Gehrig’s
  Disease.  
ALS rapidly
  deteriorates the motor neurons in the brain and the spinal cord that allow
  voluntarily control of muscle movement. As the disease progresses the muscles
  begin to waste away or atrophy, causing increased muscle weakness, paralysis,
  and inability to swallow or breathe. 
  The patient’s mind remains fully cognizant throughout the entirety of
  this agonizing process, with death most commonly occurring within two years.
Scarce
  progress has been made in the area of research, diagnoses, or treatment.  There is presently no cure.
What is Hope on the Horizon:




An adventure documentary following two HARK representatives
  Joshua Valentine and Kirk Leslie’s successful mission to summit the 48 highest mountains in New Hampshire in a
  single, 25 day trip to raise awareness and support for ALS patients and
  families.  As it follows their journey,
  the film tells the story of the patients who have rallied behind this
  mission, and serves to educate the viewers about the disease, HARK’s mission,
  and the incredible struggle an ALS patient faces each day.  It concludes with a passionate call to
  action to “Get involved and help” by joining HARK’s mission to battle ALS.

story:
Hi Everyone, 

My name is Natalie Ring, I am a 2nd year medical student at Dartmouth Medical School. This is a campaign to raise money to allow the little sister of a very dear friend of mine to continue attending Middle School in Harare, Zimbabwe. 

About Elizabeth: 

Elizabeth (she uses her middle name) is 13, and attends a girl's school. Her mother is a single parent and is unfortunately unable to work due to a health condition. Elizabeth would like be either a lawyer or a diplomat when she grows up. For the past few years, Elizabeth's big sister (my friend) has been able to cover Elizabeth's school fees by sending money from the U.S.  

About my friend: 

My friend is currently a full-time 2nd year medical student. During high school, undergraduate and her first year of medical school, she has been able to help support her family. However, due to the financial constraints of 2nd year, my friend is temporarily unable to cover Elizabeth's school fees for the next term. My friend is determined: if she could work more hours at her part-time job, she would! However, being an international student, she is limited to working a certain number of hours by immigration policy. 

The Goal: 

Elizabeth needs $515 before January 1st, 2015 in order to continue going on to 9th grade next year. The cost breakdown is outlined in the photo above - let's help her stay in school! 

This campaign is important to me because I know it would mean the world to one of my dearest friends to see her little sister be able to continue school. It further means a lot because we are given a chance to allow a driven young girl to continue her education and build a future for herself.  

A million thanks for any and all contributions towards Elizabeth's education, or for sharing this campaign with your friends!

Many thanks and happy holidays,

Natalie

(We have refrained from including pictures or any identifying information about Elizabeth, as well as my friend, in order to protect their anonymity.)

story:
Short Summary

Education One Step Ahead Nepal is the educational project started in 15 April 2006 with the help of Austrian retired people .In Nepal women literacy rate is 44.5 according to the UNESCO which is very low.Since ,2006 around more than 100 students were benefited , out of which 6 got school leaving certificate and studying higher education. Currently, project has been providing support  for 25 students from class 1 to 10. 
In Nepal many girl students does go school or drop out after primary level because of social reason and poor economic condition of Family.Every year Education One Step Ahead Nepal receive more than 200 application for scholarship but project can  only  support 25-30 students.
This campaign is for raising money for 15 girl students studying at class 6-8. These 15 girls are from very low income family that hardly manage their day to day living.They want to study and take their family out from poverty in future.But they even don't have money to buy copies and pencils.The fund that will received through this campaign is use for whole academic expenses including small baby goats which will help to  make their economic at least ok  for them in future. USD.50 is for dress and stationary while another USD.50 is for baby goat.
Donation receive from campaign will be used in more transparent way .Picture and video will be display in our social media to assure fund is use in right way.
our website is www.eosanepal.org.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need USD.1500 for 15 girl students .USD.50 will be used buying dress and stationary for student while another USD.50 will be for buying small baby goat so that girl student make in profit after one year and use for her education in future and she doesn't need to ask anybody to support her education.
  • We only provide one time support and then they support themselves for long time.
  • We receive more than 200 application for scholarship so there is high no chance we don't reach our goal.


The Impact

We have been very success in our project since 2006.Most of our fund got proper used and our donor are very happy despite their limited donation.
  • Girl's education is very important for making women more empower .In the world there are many girls who are not able to get education due to poor financial condition of family.So at least we are educating some of them no matter the size is.
  • We have been able to support 100 student since 2006.And 6 have School leaving certificate and currently working and studying. Some are studying at bachelor level and some are in +2 level.8 more students are attending school leaving certificate this year.
  • You can visit our website www.eosanepal.org to see our works.


Risks & Challenges

The main risk and challenges we have is girls dropout and early marriage . We had experience the early marriage at the age of 16 while studying class 8 and 9.

  • We have volunteer to counsel the girl students and their parent to prevent the dropout and early marriage.We have succeeded in 9 cases like before out of 12.
  • We communicate our project students at least one time in month about her education and family life.These inputs help them to movita to study more.   


Other Ways You Can Help

People can even share their idea and method to make project more better .We appreciate any kind of support because small support can change life of many people.

story:
The trip

I just finished my first year of the MSLS program at the School of Information and Library Science at UNC. Over the course of the year, I became extremely interested in digital libraries--and digital libraries in developing countries in particular. Digital libraries can help developing countries because:

  • they expand access to materials dramatically: instead of just one person, many people can use a resource at one time. 
  • they preserve aging and rare materials: there's no "wear-and-tear" in a digital library!
  • developing infrastructure: a digital library demands a certain amount of infrastructure (constant electricity, computers, network connections). Growing a country's Information and Computer Technology infrastructure has long-term benefits in today's Information Age.
In the literature on digital libraries in developing countries, there is a general consensus on the advantages of digital libraries and the challenges in implementing them. What is NOT known is how to overcome these challenges.
To bridge this gap, I am traveling to Malawi and Zambia to interview librarians who are running successful digital library projects. In the fall semester, plan to write and publish an article on how they successfully developed and maintained their digital libraries!
Flights across the world are expensive, though. But with your help, I can show librarians in developing countries how to run successful digital libraries. 

The Specifics

I will be traveling from July 28, 2014 to August 7, 2014.

  • July 28-August 1: Standing Conference of Eastern, Central and Southern African Library and Information Associations (SCECSAL) in Lilongwe, Malawi.

  • August 2-August 7: Ministry of Education in Lusaka, Zambia.

I am joining Professor Cliff Missen, director of the WiderNet Project and WiderNet@UNC. Cliff has been working in the field of digital libraries in developing countries for many years, and will be able to introduce me to the best contacts possible. 

What I Need and What You Get!

I need about $4000 to make this dream a reality. I have been given $1000 from the WiderNet Project (with whom I am traveling), and I am personally paying $1000. I am hoping to get another $1000 from various scholarships and local groups. This still leaves $1000 that I need to raise, though!

This is where you come in. Any amount you donate will warm the cockles of my heart, but higher amounts will receive perks!

  • $10-$20: Postcard from Malawi or Zambia.
  • $20-$50: Personalized piece of jewelry made by yours truly with beads from Kenya.
  • $50-$100: Invitation to four-course wine dinner in Raleigh, N.C. 
  • $100+: Bottle of wine from Westgate Wine Company in Raleigh, N.C. and handmade set of greeting cards.
If I don't reach my goal, I will still be able to keep the funds and put them towards the trip. If I exceed my goal, I will be able to subtract from the $1000 I am currently paying.

The Impact

This opportunity is truly once-in-a lifetime. I have the chance to really make a difference in an area that is of utmost importance to me and that has the potential to better people's lives.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand if you can't contribute, but please share this campaign on the social media site of your choice!

story:
Help us Take our High School Students into Nature!

We are a group of high school educators working in a Title 1 public high school in New York City.  Our belief in experiential learning propels us to give our students opportunities to interact with the world around them, including the natural world, which they have little exposure to in the middle of the most densely populated city in the country.

Last year we took an inaugural camping trip to the Appalachian Trail with 5 teachers and 20 students.  In order to make this happen, teachers donated personal funds, equipment, and asked for loans from generous friends and family to help.  

After the huge success of our first excursion, a huge interest has grown among our student body to repeat the trip.  We would like to create a more sustainable annual backpacking program at our high school by raising funds to purchase equipment, food, and supplies, and to subsidize travel costs for students.

This camping trip galvanized a community of students and teachers and created unforgettable experiences for all individuals involved.  

What We Need

The majority of our students do not own or have access to outdoor equipment, or they may come from a financial situation in which they cannot afford such items.  We would like to create a stock of equipment that can be used by a group this year and for future trips.  Your contribution will go toward the purchase of:

  • 15-20 External Frame backpacks - external frames will allow us to adjust loads and lash equipment onto packs. It also keeps the cost down.

  • 7 three- person tents

  • 20 camping mats

  • 20 × 40 degree+ sleeping bags

  • 20 ponchos - obviously for those damp occasions

  • 20 canteens - clear Nalgene bottles

  • 20 sporks

  • 1 spool of 550 paracord

  • 20 canteen cups - these are used for hot drinks/chow

  • 5 large tarps - used in conjunction with tents

  • 3 Field manuals with lensatic compasses - to learn orienteering skills

  • 3 rolls of duct tape

  • Group camp stove with fuel - used for boiling water

  • 2 First Aid kits - just in case someone gets a scratch

  • 2 Entrenching Tools or "Etool" (folding shovel) - used for digging cat holes and putting out fires

What happens when urban teenagers enter the woods:

To be honest, all kinds of things.  They get really excited about leaves.  They notice every single smell, sight, and sound.  Especially in the dark.  They take pictures of bark and small salamanders and grass clumps and pretty much everything else.  

Then their cellphones and cameras die.

And then...

They freak out a little bit and wonder what is going to happen to them.  And what happens is:  

They sweat from hiking for three miles. They guzzle water (ok, some for the first time...seriously).  They learn how to set up a tent. They work as a team to build a fire, and learn to carry their own weight so that dinner gets made.  They yell and hear their echoes.  They hear echoes from other things in the woods and get scared (quickly dashing to the "safety" of their tents).  They see what dark is and what the stars look like.  They invent scary stories and tell even more ridiculous ones.  They see a different side of the teachers and of each other that they don't see otherwise.  They sit and are quiet (for two minutes, but still...).

This trip was a transformative experience for students who attended last year.  It is experiential learning at its best, offering social, emotional and physical growth.  Our students do something they never thought they would do.  We wish to offer this opportunity to students each year.

Other Ways You Can Help

No contribution to this endeavor is too small.  If you are not personally able to contribute but can help us get the word out via your Facebook, Twitter, etc., we would greatly appreciate the help.

Thank you!
story_txt:
Help us Take our High School Students into Nature!We are a group of high school educators working in a Title 1 public high school in New York City.  Our belief in experiential learning propels us to give our students opportunities to interact with the world around them, including the natural world, which they have little exposure to in the middle of the most densely populated city in the country.Last year we took an inaugural camping trip to the Appalachian Trail with 5 teachers and 20 students.  In order to make this happen, teachers donated personal funds, equipment, and asked for loans from generous friends and family to help.  After the huge success of our first excursion, a huge interest has grown among our student body to repeat the trip.  We would like to create a more sustainable annual backpacking program at our high school by raising funds to purchase equipment, food, and supplies, and to subsidize travel costs for students.This camping trip galvanized a community of students and teachers and created unforgettable experiences for all individuals involved.  What We Need The majority of our students do not own or have access to outdoor equipment, or they may come from a financial situation in which they cannot afford such items.  We would like to create a stock of equipment that can be used by a group this year and for future trips.  Your contribution will go toward the purchase of:
15-20 External Frame backpacks - external frames will allow us to adjust loads and lash equipment onto packs. It also keeps the cost down.
7 three- person tents
20 camping mats
20 × 40 degree+ sleeping bags
20 ponchos - obviously for those damp occasions
20 canteens - clear Nalgene bottles
20 sporks
1 spool of 550 paracord
20 canteen cups - these are used for hot drinks/chow
5 large tarps - used in conjunction with tents
3 Field manuals with lensatic compasses - to learn orienteering skills

3 rolls of duct tape 
Group camp stove with fuel - used for boiling water
2 First Aid kits - just in case someone gets a scratch
2 Entrenching Tools or "Etool" (folding shovel) - used for digging cat holes and putting out fires
What happens when urban teenagers enter the woods:To be honest, all kinds of things.  They get really excited about leaves.  They notice every single smell, sight, and sound.  Especially in the dark.  They take pictures of bark and small salamanders and grass clumps and pretty much everything else.  Then their cellphones and cameras die.And then...They freak out a little bit and wonder what is going to happen to them.  And what happens is:  They sweat from hiking for three miles. They guzzle water (ok, some for the first time...seriously).  They learn how to set up a tent. They work as a team to build a fire, and learn to carry their own weight so that dinner gets made.  They yell and hear their echoes.  They hear echoes from other things in the woods and get scared (quickly dashing to the "safety" of their tents).  They see what dark is and what the stars look like.  They invent scary stories and tell even more ridiculous ones.  They see a different side of the teachers and of each other that they don't see otherwise.  They sit and are quiet (for two minutes, but still...).This trip was a transformative experience for students who attended last year.  It is experiential learning at its best, offering social, emotional and physical growth.  Our students do something they never thought they would do.  We wish to offer this opportunity to students each year.Other Ways You Can HelpNo contribution to this endeavor is too small.  If you are not personally able to contribute but can help us get the word out via your Facebook, Twitter, etc., we would greatly appreciate the help. Thank you!

story:
Our mission

Bomoyi aims to empower women and children through the fight against illiteracy, to promote access to education and to guarantee them a better future in order to durably fight poverty.

We aims to carry out our actions accross the african continent by starting with the Democratic Republic of Congo, our founder native country.

What we are doing might seem a tiny drop in the ocean compared to the sheer extent of the needs in education and health, however Bomoyi ensures to provide a regional common effort.

Who are we?

We are a dedicated team of pragmatic young professionals who want to provide congolese women and children with the best educational tools to empower themselves and be the next changemakers.
Our team is made ​​up of dynamic people and volunteers from all areas and from different continents: Africa, Asia, Europe, and America.

Nana Shodu worked for 9 years at the OECD as a project coordinator.

In the widened framework of her missions, she conducted the investments development in african countries.

She collaborated closely with the World Bank and the European Nations in order to lead concrete initiatives toward Africa.

Not limited to, she organized and set up international events between political and key opinion leaders to raise awareness about the continent most urgent development issues and to means to durably fight poverty.

The experience she gained through the years enabled her to confront the unfolding realities and the work in progress. Indeed, it also deemed imperative to implement appropriate actions to participate in the process of empowerment for the most deprived.

This has now been done with Bomoyi!

Our actions

We do believe that women are pillars of african societies especially because they give birth.

We want to women to be at the centre of our action as bearers of life.

We want them to be equipped with the skills, to pass this knowledge to children and future generations.

Bomoyi believes that women and children are the ones who hold the power to change tomorrow’s world.

We want them to get access to the basic education required for a successful socioprofessional integration.

Because our mission fall within an empowering approach, our actions will be aligned with the millenium development goals and will consist in:

1.  Eradicating extreme poverty ;

2.  Achieving universal primary education ;

3.  Promoting gender equality and empower women;

4.  Réducing child mortality;

5.  Improving maternal health;

6.  Combatting HIV/AIDS, Malaria and other diseases;

7.  Ensuring environmental sustainibility;

8.  Supporting global partnership for development ;

What We Need

Free access to education for all « No school, No future »

In the Democratic Republic of Congo, public school fees are charged therefore beyond a majority of the congolese population’s means.

By 2015, we want to bring financial support of nearly 200 children scholarships from the Nsele district.

The Bomoyi non-profit organization is funded by donations.

The school year will start on September 1st, 2014.

Then our next trip is scheduled for August 5th, 2014 in order to proceed with the payment of registration fees, to deliver school materials and the required uniforms (depending of our resources).

Our goal is to provide at first, schooling solutions for at least 50 children.

To meet our needs we must raise  € 13,000 ($ 18000)

Who are we?

We are a dedicated team of pragmatic young professionals who want to provide congolese women and children with the best educational tools to empower themselves and be the next changemakers.
Our team is made ​​up of dynamic people and volunteers from all areas and from different continents: Africa, Asia, Europe, and America.

Nana Shodu worked for 9 years at the OECD as a project coordinator.

In the widened framework of her missions, she conducted the investments development in african countries.

She collaborated closely with the World Bank and the European Nations in order to lead concrete initiatives toward Africa.

Not limited to, she organized and set up international events between political and key opinion leaders to raise awareness about the continent most urgent development issues and to means to durably fight poverty.

The experience she gained through the years enabled her to confront the unfolding realities and the work in progress. Indeed, it also deemed imperative to implement appropriate actions to participate in the process of empowerment for the most deprived.

This has now been done with Bomoyi!

Our actions

We do believe that women are pillars of african societies especially because they give birth.

We want to women to be at the centre of our action as bearers of life.

We want them to be equipped with the skills, to pass this knowledge to children and future generations.

Bomoyi believes that women and children are the ones who hold the power to change tomorrow’s world.

We want them to get access to the basic education required for a successful socioprofessional integration.

Because our mission fall within an empowering approach, our actions will be aligned with the millenium development goals and will consist in:

1. Eradicating extreme poverty ;

2. Achieving universal primary education ;

3. Promoting gender equality and empower women;

4. Réducing child mortality;

5. Improving maternal health;

6. Combatting HIV/AIDS, Malaria and other diseases;

7. Ensuring environmental sustainibility;

8. Supporting global partnership for development ;

Expenses include :

· The annual registration fees ;

· The delivering of school materials: binders, notebook, pens, pencils, sharpeners, erasers, rulers, calculators, etc.;

· The delivering of uniforms: Outfits are required to be admitted;

· The snacks / meals (depending on resources):

The majority of children are not able to eat a daily meal, due to their parents’ lack of financial resources;

Bomoyi wish to provide them one meal a day. It might be for many of them the only one of the day.

We works in the Congo field with a dynamic and volunteer team of individuals.

Constantly in touch with them, we ensure that children are schooling properly and that our project is managed carefully.

We plan frequent trips in DRC to verify our children’s situation and to be updated about their needs.

How to support Bomoyi ?

By clicking and sharing our facebook and Twitter pages, our website and our blog;


https://www.facebook.com/bomoyiorg

https://twitter.com/Bomoyiasso

http://www.bomoyi.org/nous-soutenir.html

http://www.bomoyi.blogspot.fr/

and of course via Indiegogo!

story:
中文請往下拉 (= for Chinese please scroll down)

Die Deutsch-Chinesische Kita Berlin war im Oktober 2008 die erste bilinguale Deutsch-Chinesische Kita, die in Deutschland eröffnet hat. Wir fördern den deutsch-chinesischen Sprach- und Kulturaustausch und fangen da an, wo die Zukunft beginnt: bei unseren Kindern. Dafür können wir Deine Hilfe brauchen!

Mehrsprachigkeit & interkulturelle Kompetenz

Schon heute spricht der Großteil der Weltbevölkerung Chinesisch: Rund 1,3 Mrd Menschen. Das sind fast 13% der Menschheit. Erstaunlich, dass es  trotzdem kaum chinesische Sprachförderung und Kulturaustauschprojekte gibt. Unsere Kinder kommen aus Familien, mit einem chinesischen Elternteil aber auch aus Familien mit anderem Kulturhintergrund, aber wir haben ein gemeinsames Anliegen für unsere Kinder: Das bestmögliche authentische Aufwachsen in der deutschen und chinesischen Kultur und Sprache. Deswegen benötigt die Kita zusätzliche chinesische Mitarbeiter, um ein umfangreicheres bilinguales Umfeld herzustellen. Musikalisch werden beide Sprachen stark gefördert, daher braucht die Kita auch Mittel für diesen Bereich.

 Was hast Du davon ?

 Wir glauben daran, dass eine nachhaltige Integration der chinesischen Kultur und Sprache in unsere Einwanderungsgesellschaft unerlässlich ist. Wir wollen chinesische Fachkräfte, Mitarbeiter, Kollegen, Freunde willkommen heißen. Und wir wollen, dass unsere Kinder, ob mit chinesischen Wurzeln oder ohne, die im deutschen Kulturraum aufwachsen, die chinesische Kultur verstehen lernen, sich in ihr zu Hause fühlen und ein Leben in China als Zukunftsoption sehen. Auch wenn Du selbst keine Kinder hast, profitierst Du von Kollegen, Mitarbeitern, Nachbarn, Freunden, die mit der chinesischen Kultur und Sprache vertraut sind. Die als Mittler zwischen den Welten für Annäherung und Gemeinsamkeiten sorgen. Englisch sprechen übrigens „nur“ knapp 5% der Menschen auf der Welt. Und natürlich würde niemand die Wichtigkeit der englischen Sprache und des anglo-amerikanischen Kulturraums für unsere Gesellschaft  in Frage stellen, oder?

Unser Erzieher-Team braucht alle Unterstützung

Die Grundfinanzierung der Kita ist gesichert, jedoch verlangt die gelebte Bilingualität besonderen Einsatz. Unser engagiertes Team meistert diese Herausforderung mit viel Leidenschaft. In jeder Gruppe gibt es mindestens eine deutschsprachige und eine chinesische Erzieherin, deren Bezahlung durch das Berliner Gutscheinsystem gedeckt ist. Durch gemeinsames Erleben und interaktive Alltagsgestaltung bekommen die Kinder spielerisch beide Sprachen und die Kultur beider Länder vermittelt. Da das Sprach- und Kulturumfeld deutsch ist, möchten wir einen besonders starken Akzent auf die chinesische Sprache & Kultur setzen, um den Kindern das Lernen zu erleichtern. Eine weitere chinesische Erzieherin soll dabei helfen.

12.000 Euro für fünf Monate: viel für uns, wenig für viele

In kleinen Schritten Richtung Zukunft – das gilt für uns in vielerlei Hinsicht. Wir möchten zunächst für fünf Monate die Finanzierung einer zusätzlichen chinesischen Erzieherkraft in der Drachengruppe (das ist die Krippe, für Kinder von 1 bis 3 Jahren) sichern. Zudem soll der deutsch-chinesische Musikunterricht gefördert werden. Wir haben einmal die Woche eine deutsche Musiklehrerin zu Besuch. Schön wäre, wenn wir darüber hinaus auch eine chinesische Musiklehrerin finanzieren könnten. Sollten wir nicht die ganze Summe zusammenbekommen, werden wir eine chinesische Aushilfe so lange finanzieren, bis das Geld alle ist. Und dann den nächsten Schritt planen. Einen nach dem anderen. 2008 waren wir die erste deutsch-chinesische Kita  in Deutschland, glücklicherweise inzwischen mit einigen Nachahmern – auch damals haben wir mit einem kleinen Schritt begonnen.  

Komm uns besuchen!

Egal, ob Du uns finanziell unterstützen möchtest oder nach anderen Möglichkeiten für ein Engagement suchst: Wir freuen uns immer über interessierten Besuch (nur nach Terminabsprache). Die Deutsch-Chinesische Kita befindet sich in Berlin-Prenzlauer Berg im internationalen und kinderfreundlichen Kiez zwischen Helmholtz- und Kollwitzplatz und bietet ganztägige Betreuung von 8-17 Uhr für Kinder von 1-6 Jahren durchgängig in deutscher und chinesischer Sprache an.

In 2010 haben wir die Kita erweitert, um zusätzliche Krippenplätze für Kinder unter 3 Jahren zu schaffen, so dass wir seit August insgesamt 27 Plätze anbieten können. Gefördert wurde diese Erweiterung durch das Krippenausbau-Programm der Bundesregierung.


Als gemeinnütziger Nonprofit Verein sind wir berechtigt eine Spendenbescheinigung auszustellen laut Freistellungsbescheid vom Finanzamt für Körperschaften l , Stnr. 27/635/53618.
Bei Bedarf einer Spendenquittung wenden sie sich bitte an folgende Emailadresse: Info@daschinabuero.org (unter Angabe von Name, Adresse und Überweisungsnachweiss)


柏林德中幼儿园：为了培养孩子在未来的全球化世界中有可持续的适应 。
   
从2008年十月开始，柏林德中幼儿园是在德国领先开创的第一家。
孩子是我们的未来，我们推动德中语言和文化交流的开始也是未来开始的地方。
为了孩子，我们需要你的支持！

多语言与跨文化能力

在今天全世界大部分的人口说汉语，大约有13亿人。这是近13％的世界人口。
令人惊讶的是在德国仍然只有很少的中国语言推动和文化交流项目。
我们的孩子来自各种家庭，有中德家庭也有其他文化背景的家庭。为了孩子们，我们有一个共同的心愿：就是让我们的孩子在最好的真正的德中文化和语言中成长。
为了打造一个更宽广的双语环境，因此幼儿园需要额外的中国幼教人员。
为了加大双语的音乐方面推动，因此幼儿园在方面也需要加重投入。

你的受益是什么？

我们不要扮演高等的幼儿园，也不认为自己是很好强，望子成龙的家长：我们相信在德国的移民社会里中国文化和语言的可持续融合是不可或缺的。
我们要欢迎中国的专业人事，员工，同事，朋友。
我们还希望，在德国文化里长大的这些孩子，无论他们有没有中国血缘，都能理解和学会中国文化，就感觉像在自己的母文化里一样，而且看到未来可能选择在中国生活。
即使你自己没有孩子，你也会受益于这些理解中国文化和语言的同事，员工，邻居以及朋友。这些人会拉近文化的距离和找到文化的共同性。在全世界「只有」将近5％的人说英语。当然没有人会对英语和我们所讨论的英美文化对于德国社会的重要性提出质疑。

我们的幼儿园教师小组需要你的各样支持与援助

德中幼儿园的基本财务状况是平衡的，不过双语学制的实施，却需要更多特殊的努力。我们有奉献精神的团队以十足的热诚迎接这个挑战。幼儿园里每组小孩都至少有一位德语教师和一位华语教师，这些教师们的薪水由柏林市政府补助。透过共同体验与互动的日常生活，小孩以游戏方式学会了解两国的语言和文化。由于柏林语言和生活环境是德语的，我们希望把重点放在华语和中华文化上面，好让孩子们学习便利。我们希望再多一位华语教师帮助我们。

一万二欧元补助五个月：对我们是很大的帮助，对多数人是小数字的集合。

一小步一小步的迈向未来，是我们的目标。首先，我们希望在下五个月能为「小龙小组」（１－３岁小组）增多一位华语教师。其次，希望德中语的音乐课程能加强。我们目前每周有一位德语音乐教师上课，如果也能有一位华语音乐教师就太美好了。倘若我们得到你们够多的援助，我们就可暂时多聘请一位华语教师，直到这额外的援助用完，再计划下一步。
我们是在２００８年成立的德国第一个德中双语幼儿园，今天已经有其他的双语幼儿园跟上了──我们当年也是一步一步走过来的。

欢迎光临参观！

不论你是否能援助我们或你用何种方式帮助我们，我们都欢迎你的访问！德中幼儿园的地点在Helmholtz- und Kollwitzplatz 之间的Berlin-Prenzlauer Berg，是一个国际性的儿童友善环境。我们每天从８－１７点提供照护幼儿的德中语全日服务。
我们在２０１０年扩大了规模，增加了三岁以下的托婴服务，所以我们从八月开始共有２７个名额。这个扩大规模计划也由德国联邦托婴计划补助。

Auch wenn Du selbst keine Kinder hast, profitierst Du von Kollegen, Mitarbeitern, Nachbarn, Freunden, die mit der chinesischen Kultur und Sprache vertraut sind. Die als Mittler zwischen den Welten für Annäherung und Gemeinsamkeiten sorgen. Englisch sprechen übrigens „nur“ knapp 5% der Menschen auf der Welt. Und natürlich würde niemand die Wichtigkeit der englischen Sprache und des anglo-amerikanischen Kulturraums für unsere Gesellschaft  in Frage stellen, oder?Unser Erzieher-Team braucht alle UnterstützungDie Grundfinanzierung der Kita ist gesichert, jedoch verlangt die gelebte Bilingualität besonderen Einsatz. Unser engagiertes Team meistert diese Herausforderung mit viel Leidenschaft. In jeder Gruppe gibt es mindestens eine deutschsprachige und eine chinesische Erzieherin, deren Bezahlung durch das Berliner Gutscheinsystem gedeckt ist. Durch gemeinsames Erleben und interaktive Alltagsgestaltung bekommen die Kinder spielerisch beide Sprachen und die Kultur beider Länder vermittelt. Da das Sprach- und Kulturumfeld deutsch ist, möchten wir einen besonders starken Akzent auf die chinesische Sprache & Kultur setzen, um den Kindern das Lernen zu erleichtern. Eine weitere chinesische Erzieherin soll dabei helfen.12.000 Euro für fünf Monate: viel für uns, wenig für vieleIn kleinen Schritten Richtung Zukunft – das gilt für uns in vielerlei Hinsicht. Wir möchten zunächst für fünf Monate die Finanzierung einer zusätzlichen chinesischen Erzieherkraft in der Drachengruppe (das ist die Krippe, für Kinder von 1 bis 3 Jahren) sichern. Zudem soll der deutsch-chinesische Musikunterricht gefördert werden. Wir haben einmal die Woche eine deutsche Musiklehrerin zu Besuch. Schön wäre, wenn wir darüber hinaus auch eine chinesische Musiklehrerin finanzieren könnten. Sollten wir nicht die ganze Summe zusammenbekommen, werden wir eine chinesische Aushilfe so lange finanzieren, bis das Geld alle ist. Und dann den nächsten Schritt planen. Einen nach dem anderen. 2008 waren wir die erste deutsch-chinesische Kita  in Deutschland, glücklicherweise inzwischen mit einigen Nachahmern – auch damals haben wir mit einem kleinen Schritt begonnen.  Komm uns besuchen!Egal, ob Du uns finanziell unterstützen möchtest oder nach anderen Möglichkeiten für ein Engagement suchst: Wir freuen uns immer über interessierten Besuch (nur nach Terminabsprache). Die Deutsch-Chinesische Kita befindet sich in Berlin-Prenzlauer Berg im internationalen und kinderfreundlichen Kiez zwischen Helmholtz- und Kollwitzplatz und bietet ganztägige Betreuung von 8-17 Uhr für Kinder von 1-6 Jahren durchgängig in deutscher und chinesischer Sprache an.In 2010 haben wir die Kita erweitert, um zusätzliche Krippenplätze für Kinder unter 3 Jahren zu schaffen, so dass wir seit August insgesamt 27 Plätze anbieten können. Gefördert wurde diese Erweiterung durch das Krippenausbau-Programm der Bundesregierung.Als gemeinnütziger Nonprofit Verein sind wir berechtigt eine Spendenbescheinigung auszustellen laut Freistellungsbescheid vom Finanzamt für Körperschaften l , Stnr. 27/635/53618.Bei Bedarf einer Spendenquittung wenden sie sich bitte an folgende Emailadresse: Info@daschinabuero.org (unter Angabe von Name, Adresse und Überweisungsnachweiss)柏林德中幼儿园：为了培养孩子在未来的全球化世界中有可持续的适应 。   从2008年十月开始，柏林德中幼儿园是在德国领先开创的第一家。 孩子是我们的未来，我们推动德中语言和文化交流的开始也是未来开始的地方。为了孩子，我们需要你的支持！多语言与跨文化能力在今天全世界大部分的人口说汉语，大约有13亿人。这是近13％的世界人口。令人惊讶的是在德国仍然只有很少的中国语言推动和文化交流项目。我们的孩子来自各种家庭，有中德家庭也有其他文化背景的家庭。为了孩子们，我们有一个共同的心愿：就是让我们的孩子在最好的真正的德中文化和语言中成长。为了打造一个更宽广的双语环境，因此幼儿园需要额外的中国幼教人员。为了加大双语的音乐方面推动，因此幼儿园在方面也需要加重投入。你的受益是什么？我们不要扮演高等的幼儿园，也不认为自己是很好强，望子成龙的家长：我们相信在德国的移民社会里中国文化和语言的可持续融合是不可或缺的。我们要欢迎中国的专业人事，员工，同事，朋友。我们还希望，在德国文化里长大的这些孩子，无论他们有没有中国血缘，都能理解和学会中国文化，就感觉像在自己的母文化里一样，而且看到未来可能选择在中国生活。即使你自己没有孩子，你也会受益于这些理解中国文化和语言的同事，员工，邻居以及朋友。这些人会拉近文化的距离和找到文化的共同性。在全世界「只有」将近5％的人说英语。当然没有人会对英语和我们所讨论的英美文化对于德国社会的重要性提出质疑。我们的幼儿园教师小组需要你的各样支持与援助德中幼儿园的基本财务状况是平衡的，不过双语学制的实施，却需要更多特殊的努力。我们有奉献精神的团队以十足的热诚迎接这个挑战。幼儿园里每组小孩都至少有一位德语教师和一位华语教师，这些教师们的薪水由柏林市政府补助。透过共同体验与互动的日常生活，小孩以游戏方式学会了解两国的语言和文化。由于柏林语言和生活环境是德语的，我们希望把重点放在华语和中华文化上面，好让孩子们学习便利。我们希望再多一位华语教师帮助我们。一万二欧元补助五个月：对我们是很大的帮助，对多数人是小数字的集合。一小步一小步的迈向未来，是我们的目标。首先，我们希望在下五个月能为「小龙小组」（１－３岁小组）增多一位华语教师。其次，希望德中语的音乐课程能加强。我们目前每周有一位德语音乐教师上课，如果也能有一位华语音乐教师就太美好了。倘若我们得到你们够多的援助，我们就可暂时多聘请一位华语教师，直到这额外的援助用完，再计划下一步。我们是在２００８年成立的德国第一个德中双语幼儿园，今天已经有其他的双语幼儿园跟上了──我们当年也是一步一步走过来的。欢迎光临参观！不论你是否能援助我们或你用何种方式帮助我们，我们都欢迎你的访问！德中幼儿园的地点在Helmholtz- und Kollwitzplatz 之间的Berlin-Prenzlauer Berg，是一个国际性的儿童友善环境。我们每天从８－１７点提供照护幼儿的德中语全日服务。我们在２０１０年扩大了规模，增加了三岁以下的托婴服务，所以我们从八月开始共有２７个名额。这个扩大规模计划也由德国联邦托婴计划补助。

story:
Short Summary

"Be hungry but noble-minded, be threadbare but clean. "

Vietnamese Proverb

My name is Carlyn Barrow, I am 25 years old, and I have just been accepted into a program to obtain my TESOL (Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages) certification, and spend a year teaching in Vietnam. I have been granted this incredible opportunity through LanguageCorps, the largest provider of TESOL/Teaching Abroad programs in the industry. More information about LanguageCorps can be found below.

http://www.languagecorps.com/about

What I Need & What You Get


  • The cost of the TESOL program in Vietnam is approximately 1745.00, USD which includes housing and accommodations (both in Vietnam and Phnom Penh, Cambodia, where LanguageCorps Asia training center is located), course materials, in-country support, cell phone, and basic travel insurance. Not included in the course fee is airfare (estimated at 750-1,100 USD at the moment) and visa fees (around $300). Factoring in the cut Indigogo takes from the campaign and  cost to purchase and ship perks, I need to raise a total of $4,500
  • For perks-I have chosen to partner with two fair trade craft organizations out of Vietnam: Craft Link has a focus on ethnic minorities, street children and artisans with disabilities, while Mai Handcrafts focuses on disadvantaged women. All of the perks for this campaign were chosen to focus on Vietnam's celebrated culinary traditions.
  • If I don't reach my goal, I still receive the funds from the campaign, which will still greatly help in any given portion of the process.

The Impact

  • Getting my TESOL certification is a critical step in my career goal in working with international students and communities here in the US, which I began pursuing after committing to two years of full-time missions work at Urbana '12. At the same time, it is enabling me to respond to a critical need in Southeast Asia for qualified English Language teachers. Vietnam in particular has suffered an influx of "backpacker" teachers, travelers who are hired to teach without the necessary experience.
  • Each of the perks you receive with your donation supplies much-needed income for artists in Vietnam who are trying to make a living making traditional crafts that have been passed down through generations. This has been made possible through two organizations operating under the World Fair Trade Organization (WFTO). All of the crafts featured on this campaign have been paid for in full, with a price designed to meet all of the artist's daily needs.


Other Ways You Can Help

Donations of any amount are enormously appreciated! $1 is $1 closer to my goal. If you cannot afford to support financially, that’s ok. Anyone can have a huge impact on this by helping spread the word. I don’t have a huge internet presence, so I would absolutely love it if you shared this page through your twitter, blog, tumblr, website, or anywhere else! Indiegogo also has share tools that make it super easy.

Thank you so much! And check back often for updates!

story:
What is Cultivating Women's Leadership?

Why do I want to attend this 6 day intensive program in the California Redwoods?

  • This leadership conference is a opportunity to increase self capacity; my ultimate intention is to use the experience to create self confidence and knowing of purpose for my natural talents and abilities. I want to leave with bravery to be the most effective and integrated person I can be. 
  • The community of women involved in this training is intentionally diverse in order to surface and appreciate the many ways leadership can look. These women are all building communities around maximizing social, environmental and spiritual good-- just like me. Through our differences we will find inspiration and creative solutions for our individual passions.
  • We will also build a network. I want to be a conduit for the enriching work happening in the Bioneer's community to reach our community.
An excerpt from the Cultivating Women's Leadership Training site:

"The program’s uniqueness is in it's systemic or inter-sectional approach to leadership. Rather than focusing on either internal work or skill‐building for external change, CWL connects personal awareness practices with increased capacity to be bold and effective multi‐cultural leaders in the world."

When I read the above,I am ignited by the momentum that intentional vulnerability and authentic relating can create. I believe these are the true drivers of creating a healthier, more joyful, responsive world. I see the need for leadership to reveal these frameworks as viable solutions for global issues,    

Overview of the Expenses

  • The total cost is $1950 for the tuition, lodging, and meals.
  • My flight to San Francisco will be ~$400. I will then need to drive, bus, (suggestions?) to Ben Lommond-- just north of Santa Cruz.                             (I would love to hear from anyone who knows of cheaper travel options, different airports, friends already driving etc!)
  • I have received a $950 partial scholarship to cover half of the tuition. Yay!
  • But I need to raise $1,000 by May 1st (my 24th birthday!!) in order to pay the full tuition and secure my spot. 
  • With your contribution, I'd also love to shower you in love too! I will be offering a formal class after my return based on the training, as well as one-on-one Self Integration mentoring. Other tokens of appreciation include: photo prints from my time in the Redwoods, commissioned artwork, CWL recipe book, harmonizing lessons, dinner parties...fun stuff! See below.

Why your support matters to me

I learned about this conference a year ago, felt inspired by it and hoped  I could attend. Now, a year later I find myself no longer dreaming about it but rather making it happen! I also really appreciate that my community can support me in this endeavor. After all, it's for all of us!

All of the money raised will go directly to Bioneer's Cultivating Women's Leadership Training. Find out more about the organization here.

Other Ways You Can Help

This is a whirl wind of a campaign, I understand if it's not a good time for you financially. If you feel called to help however, please share about my efforts with someone you think will feel inspired to help. You are awesome! Thank you!
