story:
What is the Kigali Reading Center?

Through straightforward, engaging, and accessible literacy programs, the nonprofit Kigali Reading Center will offer children in Kigali, Rwanda, the opportunity to increase their English skills and embrace the challenges of an ever-changing world.

A workforce fluent in English is a key component to realizing Rwanda's national economic goal to become a hub of business and technology in Africa. On an individual basis, English proficiency opens up education and employment opportunities, a way to break the cycle of poverty. Yet Rwanda has experienced difficulties in finding adequate foreign and domestic instructors to teach English. In 2009, out of Rwanda's 31,000 primary school teachers, only 4,700 were trained in English.

The Kigali Reading Center will encourage English language literacy for students in Kigali by fostering tutoring relationships and increasing access to engaging books, all free of charge for the children of Kigali who need it most. Weekly group story time, open to all in the community, will be a time for adults and children to enjoy stories together while improving their English comprehension. An informal lending library of books will be available for all in the community to borrow and enjoy. Our long-term vision is to create a safe, nurturing space where students can learn English side-by-side with volunteer mentors.



Who we are…


 Parfait Gasana did not speak English 9 years ago when he moved to the United States from Rwanda. It was through the help provided by a tutoring program in New Haven that he was able to learn English. He went on to pursue an undergraduate degree in political science and human rights at the University of Connecticut. Currently, He is finishing his Master's Degree in international relations at the University of Massachusetts Boston. Growing up in exile, his father always told him to embrace education because in it laid the secret to breaking the cycle of poverty.  

Wade Cedar was raised in poverty by a single mother and is the youngest of four boys. He was homeless for a period of time and has lived with many friends throughout his adolescent years. Wade is the first to graduate high school in his family and went on to finish number one in his program at the University of Massachusetts Boston with a 4.0 GPA. Wade is currently pursuing a Master's degree in international relations at the University of Massachusetts Boston.

We are determined to offer others the opportunity that education has provided us.  


What Your Money is Funding

The contributions we collect from this fundraiser will help sustain the reading center for a complete year! The city of Kigali has agreed to grant us a space to host the reading center. Here is a list of the expenses your donations will help to cover:

- Book collection

- Book shipment from the U.S. to Rwanda

- Furniture (locally sourced in Kigali to stimulate the local economy)

- Office supplies

- Computers & laptops for the staff and students

- Staff funding (the reading center will have three full-time employees)

If the fundraiser is unable to reach our goal of $24,100 (a full years worth of funding), we will have to scale back our services and decrease the number of children we are able to serve. Contribute now to get in on our exciting and creative perks so that we do not have to scale back our efforts. You can help make this project a great success by contributing today. 


The Impact You Can Make

The literacy rate in Rwanda is an unacceptable 66% (World Bank). There clearly exists a need for organizations such as the Kigali Reading Center. Your contribution help to improve the literacy skills of Rwanda's children and gives them an opportunity for a better life. There is only a single public library in the whole country of Rwanda, and the children are eager to have the opportunity to interact with quality books.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot make a donation there are still a number of ways you can help!

- Blast this fundraising link throughout your network! We will raise more funding if we reach a broader network of donors. With a couple of clicks on your mouse we can exponentially widen our net of potential donors. 

- We are always looking for quality children's books to stack the library shelves

story:
Let's Cheer On Literacy!

What started as a collaboration between three community organizations - Big Thought, bcWORKSHOP, and Dallas Public Libraries – to build an initial network of 20 Little Free Libraries, has inspired people across the Dallas-Fort Worth area to join the cause. Cheerios and Little Free Library® want your help to support this grassroots effort—to improve literacy and build stronger communities—by helping them raise enough funds to put up an additional 50 Little Free Libraries throughout the Dallas-Fort Worth area!

Cheerios™ believes that when people come together, anything is possible. That’s why, when we saw that extraordinary individuals were joining together to improve literacy by establishing a network of Little Free Libraries across the Dallas-Fort Worth area, we just had to cheer them on and help invest in their efforts!

Why Little Free Libraries

When children make reading an everyday activity, they not only unleash their imagination — they establish a lifelong love of learning. Our hope is to increase literacy and inspire young dreamers by building Little Free Libraries across Dallas-Fort Worth neighborhoods.

The Impact

·  $17,500 is our goal, to subsidize the construction costs of up to 50 Little Free Libraries across the Dallas-Fort Worth area

·  Any additional funds we raise (over our $17,500 goal) will go towards establishing Little Free Libraries in surrounding rural areas of Dallas and Fort Worth.

What We Need and What You Get

The money we raise will go directly towards funding subsidizing the construction costs of up to 50 Little Free Libraries across the Dallas-Fort Worth area. Please help us cheer on their effort and reach our goal!

Contribute Today! Give generously to support literacy and build strong communities through a network of Little Free Libraries in the Dallas-Ft. Worth area.

Spread the Word! Ask your family, friends, coworkers and communities to help share our campaign through Indiegogo and Facebook. Share a post, share our video – tell people why you care about Little Free Libraries!

$1 - Encourage Reading
Feel great about helping us move one step closer to our goal.

$5 - Feel Good Five
Sometimes it just feels good to give. Share your passion for reading while earning our eternal thanks with this small but mighty donation.

$15 - Robot Desktop Wallpaper
This popular Robot illustration from Bee Things will look awesome on your desktop, tablet or smart phone. Give $5 today and we’ll send you a link to this downloadable digital treat.

$15 - Buy a Book
There is no library without books! With your contribution we will stock one Little Free Library with a book. Go ahead and give someone an escape into adventure, mystery, laughter or love by donating one book to a Little Free Library.

$15 - Desktop Wallpaper 3-Pack
Show your love of reading across all your digital devices with our Bee Things Wallpaper Series. Personalize each individual device with a Fairy, Robot, or Pirate illustration. Donate $15 for a link to this downloadable digital treat.

$25 - Your Name in a Little Library
Be known forever as a supporter of literacy! Your name will be written on a plaque and attached to one of the 50 Little Free Libraries in the Dallas-Fort Worth area!

$25 - Send Books to a Kid 
Everyone loves receiving something special in the mail - especially kids. For your generosity, we'll send your favorite little reader a 5-pack of bilingual children's stories from the Cheerios™ Cheer on Reading program. We have limited sets - get yours now!


$40 - Limited-Edition Robot Screenprint
Created exclusively for this campaign by husband-and-wife design team bee things in Dallas, this dapper little robot is a limited-edition print any child (or teacher) will love. This is a 16" x 20" screen print.


$40 - Limited-Edition Fairy Screenprint
Created exclusively for this campaign by husband-and-wife design team bee things in Dallas, this kind and well-intentioned fairy is a limited-edition print any child (or teacher) will love. This is a 16" x 20" screenprint.


$40 - Limited-Edition Pirate Screenprint
Created exclusively for this campaign by husband-and-wife design team bee things in Dallas, this swashbuckling and well-read pirate is a limited-edition print any child (or teacher) will love. This is a 16" x 20" screenprint.


$50 - A Limited Edition Print + A Desktop Wallpaper 3-Pack
When you help us get even closer to our 50 Little Free Libraries goal with a donation of $75, we’ll send you a limited edition Bee Things print of your choice and a link to Bee Things easy to download desktop wallpaper 3-pack.

$100 - Limited-Edition Art Collection
Get the entire set of limited-edition screenprints created exclusively for this Little Free Libraries campaign. (Let's be honest, they're just so cute and fun - it may be too difficult to choose just one.) Receive the complete set of limited-edition Robot, Fairy, and Pirate screenprints. Each print is 16" x 20" in dimension.


$250 - Let Them Read Books!
Little Free Libraries may be small, but they can hold enough books to bring joy and excitement to an entire neighborhood. With contribution at this level, we'll stock an entire Little Free Library with a collection of books.


$350 - Sponsor an Entire Library
Little Free Libraries create community wherever they go. For your incredible generosity, we will include a plaque on this Little Free Library featuring you or a loved one as the donor. 



Frequently Asked Questions

Where will my money go?

All proceeds donated to this campaign will go directly toward subsidizing the cost of up to 50 Little Free Libraries in the Dallas-Fort Worth area. 

To learn more about the Little Free Library organization, please visit http://littlefreelibrary.org. If we exceed our goal of $17,500, the additional funds will go toward subsidizing additional Little Free Libraries in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

What are other ways to contribute to the cause?

Spread the Word! Ask your family, friends, coworkers and communities to help share our campaign through Indiegogo and Facebook. Share a post, share our video – tell people why you care about Little Free Libraries!

Stay connected. Check back often as our campaign unfolds to see updates and new perks. To learn more about our shared commitment to reading please go to Cheerios.com/cheeronreading or LittleFreeLibrary.org

© General Mills

story:
I am a startup guy and many of my projects failed, for multiple reasons.

Now, based on all the lessons learned, I am doing a big scale product experiment, while documenting the whole journey, speaking and writing about it.  

You will love this project if you are into play /code / robots / travel / makers / entrepreneurship or wonder what is like to:

  • Start a US company in 90 days... or not, from zero;
  • Get through failures, co-create with random strangers, use couchsurfing, pitch ideas, take hardware workshops, have crazy fun, get lost, manage big debt, fall in love, write a minibook, hitchhike, learn to code at MIT and train to run a marathon;
  • Be ready to fail multiple times and document your experience.



The are several things I see as value: 

  • It's an experiment on what it is to take big risks and fail big time; how is it to live and launch a company as a foreigner in USA, in just 90 days. What is like to connect with local talents and  co-create. As an experiment it can be a total failure but it's fun.
  • It's a resource - I will take interviews with US makers, designers, entrepreneurs etc. I will write blog articles and share my experience with everyone who is connected to this campaign and outside of it.
  • It's a journey about open hardware, makers and the future technologies that may take shape around Qodemo.com


The 90 days journey will be divided between San Francisco, New York, and most of it - Boston. Below is a timeline with the main To DOs:

Note: The exact timeline is a subject to minor changes.

I am a startup guy and many of my projects failed, for multiple reasons.Now, based on all the lessons learned, I am doing a big scale product experiment, while documenting the whole journey, speaking and writing about it.  You will love this project if you are into play /code / robots / travel / makers / entrepreneurship or wonder what is like to:
Start a US company in 90 days... or not, from zero;
Get through failures, co-create with random strangers, use couchsurfing, pitch ideas, take hardware workshops, have crazy fun, get lost, manage big debt, fall in love, write a minibook, hitchhike, learn to code at MIT and train to run a marathon;
Be ready to fail multiple times and document your experience.










The are several things I see as value: 


It's an experiment on what it is to take big risks and fail big time; how is it to live and launch a company as a foreigner in USA, in just 90 days. What is like to connect with local talents and  co-create. As an experiment it can be a total failure but it's fun.

It's a resource - I will take interviews with US makers, designers, entrepreneurs etc. I will write blog articles and share my experience with everyone who is connected to this campaign and outside of it.
It's a journey about open hardware, makers and the future technologies that may take shape around Qodemo.com



The 90 days journey will be divided between San Francisco, New York, and most of it - Boston. Below is a timeline with the main To DOs:





Note: The exact timeline is a subject to minor changes.

story:
Beds For Kids, Inc.

Beds For Kids, Inc. and Bridging RVA has partnered to provide 100 beds to 100 children in one day on September 27, 2014 in Chesterfield, Va.

Beds For Kids, Inc. has been providing free beds to children in need since 2005.  We provide assistance to over 600 children each year and yet the need continues to grow. 

  • This is the room of the first child we helped with a bed.  He was two years old and sleeping on a broken crib, we delivered a twin bed and a room makeover.

  • David (above) has Celiac Disease and with this comes autoimmune disorder.  For David, having a bed to sleep on meant a possible life or death situation.  He was sleeping on a dirty floor with his brother and sister.  His young parents, as hard as they worked, could not afford beds with the medical bills they had.

  • Dante came home at 17 and told his Mom that his girlfriend was pregnant. His family home was filled with his two siblings, Mother and Father and his Aunt and Uncle and cousin that has Autism.  But Dante knew his family loved him and he wanted to do the right thing. Dante's mother turned to Beds For Kids for help when she found out that it wasn't one child on the way but twins.  

What We Need

We need $25,000 to provide 100 new beds to 100 children.  While the need for beds is an ever present reality and will far surpass this goal.  We are partnering with BridgingRVA.com to deliver 100 beds in one day on September 27, 2014 to 100 children.

Each bed has a cost of $250 and provides a child with a new twin mattress, box spring, bed frame, linen, comforter and new pillow. 


The Impact and Why Beds For Kids

There are so many worthy causes that need our help.  Children need food, clothing, shelter.  Why provide a bed to a child?  
  • Children do on average 60% better in school if they gain a good night's rest.  Imagine sharing a sofa with your brother and sister and trying to get a good night's sleep.
  • When you have no other place to crash after school you head to your bedroom.  Imagine the only thing in your bedroom is a hard floor.  Would you feel safe and secure in your environment?
Providing a $250 bed to a child sleeping on the floor provides love, support and security for an average of 15 years of their lives.  The benefit of a  good night's sleep could change their future.


    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Ask friends and family to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Share on all Social Media.
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
    • We accept matching corporate gifts. Beds For Kids Donations
    • Your organization can contact us about a mission week or team building day.  mail@bedsforkids.us
    • Volunteer on September 27, 2014 in Chesterfield, Va  go to Bridging RVA


    You can not give a better gift than an opportunity "UP" for a child.  We cannot ask for anything more of you than the love you share when you help these children.  They are our passion and You are our answered prayers!  Thank you for your gifts.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Danielle Williams and I worked in Arusha Tanzania with the Umoja Music School from 2011-2013 teaching piano, flute, and voice. During that time, I had the chance to meet a young man named Phillipo. This incredibly hard-working teenager immediately stood out to me. In a place like Tanzania, where the education system discourages critical thinking and promotes a "repeat what I say" methodology, Phillipo has somehow managed to come forth a strong, independent-minded, and extremely intelligent young man. 

On his own initiative, Phillipo applied and auditioned for a music scholarship at the Braeburn International School in Arusha, Tanzania. He found out about this opportunity very last-minute and had only one day to prepare the music he would perform. Astoundingly, (though not as much to those of us who know Phillipo) he passed the audition and was granted an 85% scholarship. 

This opportunity will change Phillipo's life. It will provide him with world-class teachers, allow him to take courses in the advanced sciences and aviation that he is so interested in, will give him opportunities to again study music, take piano lessons, and perform with peers who will challenge and inspire him. The school will help him to prepare for international standard exams like the SATs, allowing him to apply to the top universities in Africa, Europe, and USA.  

Yet Phillipo comes from a family of 5 children and his parents and brothers struggle to pay even the Tanzanian Government School fees. In order for Phillipo to attend the International school, $3,100 (the other 15%) must still be paid. 

What We Need & What You Get

Here are the costs to attend the school:

$12,340/year for tuition

$300/year -- the amount Phillipo's family will contribute to his education

$2,000/year-- Remaining cost of tuition NOT covered in scholarship 

$500/year-- activity fee NOT covered in scholarship 

$600/year-- transport and food NOT covered in scholarship

Total needed to fund: $2,800

    Risks & Challenges

    I am now based back in the USA, but visited Tanzania and Phillipo just before he auditioned for the scholarship. The distance and delay in communication certainly prove to be inconveniences when working and handling money between USA and Tanzania, but I am in good communication with the head of the International School as well as my previous organization, Umoja Music School so as to facilitate clear and quick communication about Phillipo, his schooling, and financials. Additionally, I have many friends who live in Arusha who are equally passionate about Phillipo's success and education. They will help to ensure he has a support network of adults, educators, and friends which he can rely on in tough or stressful times. While this donation/sponsorship will remain anonymous to Phillipo, he knows that he has my absolute support in his educational and musical endeavors. We continue to communicate, chat, and write on a regular basis.

story:
DON’T WAIT FOR OTHER PEOPLE TO CONTRIBUTE...START FROM YOURSELF AND LEAD THE WAY! 

EVERYONE CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE! 

EVERY CONTRIBUTION COUNTS! 

 

 

 

 

WHY DO I NEED YOUR SUPPORT? 

 

My name is Irena and I am twenty-five years old. My professional experience is in the Serbian NGO and activism fields. I have been accepted to the University of Melbourne to do my Masters in Public Policy and Management. The faculty awarded me 100 points credit, in recognition of my relevant professional experience and previous studies. This means that I need to pay a half of total tuition fees if I want to continue my studies. I am sure that I can succeed with your support!

 

The average monthly salary in Serbia is $400 and that makes paying for international studies impossible. Furthermore, Serbian students are not eligible to receive Australia Awards. Why, then, wouldn’t I pursue my Masters in my own country? The answer is simple - because a Masters in Public Policy doesn’t exist in Serbia and only people who study abroad can bring new knowledge back to my country.

 

I am convinced that studying at the Melbourne School of Government, one of the world’s most reputable and innovative schools, will put me in a strong position for career opportunities in the field of international development – a field in which, after graduation, I wish to be involved professionally. I would like to work in development projects in countries undergoing democratization, focusing on fields that are of vital importance for their success such as: governance, open development, community-driven development, strengthening institutions, public management reform, developing policy-based political parties, and cooperation between non-profit organizations and government. Using knowledge acquired during the graduate program for solving real-world problems and conveying experience hitherto gained in the Western Balkans in processes of democratization in regions of the world represents a real challenge that I would love to pursue. 

MY EDUCATION 

I have a BA with Honours in Political Science, with a concentration in International Affairs. I graduated from the University of Belgrade, Faculty of Political Science, as one of the top 20 students in my year. During the course of my academic studies I had the opportunity to gain extensive knowledge in political theory, international relations, governance, economy, law and EU policies. Moreover, I was very active in extra-curricular activities, particularly as an Elected Students’ Representative in the Quality Assurance Commission at the faculty, and a member of the UN Club. 

 

YOUTH ACTIVISM 

As a twenty-year-old student, I established a non-governmental organization Youth Umbrella (Omladinski kisobran - OK) with a group of my friends in order to encourage my peers to take a more active role in the problem-solving and decision-making processes of our local community. From my perspective, one of the organisation’s greatest achievements was to nurture and support members in their respective initiatives. They became pioneers and many of them continue to be socially engaged individuals contributing to the well-being of society.

Even after I started developing my career out of youth organisations I remained dedicated to supporting young individuals, particularly in my hometown, by advising them how to organize activities, helping them to promote projects and find donations, and by giving lectures and training sessions at their seminars and camps. 

 

 

*Organizing and implementing the “Eco Camp Project” in cooperation with the Ministry of Environment. For two years in a row, this project gathered 40 students for a one-week summer camp.

                                     

 

*In cooperation with the Ministry of Youth and Sports, organizing and implementing the “Youth are the Law Project” for 30 high school students. As a direct result of this project, a network of local community youth leaders was established.

 

 

* Conducting training sessions on human rights and discrimination at camps organized by the Serbian Union of Young Activist and Youth Initiative for Human Rights for high school students from Western Balkans. I helped these youth organize several camps in order to challenge prejudice and stereotypes in the region.

                                            

 

* Visiting the Summer Mathematics Camp in my hometown Sabac, after I helped young mathematicians to organize the largest mathematics camp in the Balkans, which gathered over 140 participants.

               

 

*Serving the community 

 

 

 

POLITICAL EDUCATION AND PUBLIC POLICY 

 

* Presenting my first public policy proposal as a participant in a one-year-long “Evidence-Based Public Policy Program,” organised by National Democratic Institute (NDI). Based on my performance in this programme, considered to be outstanding, I was invited to work as an intern for the NDI Serbian Policy Development Program, where I worked on developing policy-based political parties.

                

 

*Attending FNF - International Academy of Leadership in Germany as one of 25 selected world leaders.

 

* Leading a team that simulates presidential elections campaign at NDI Advanced School of Political Skills

 

        

* Giving lectures on policy-making process hosted by the German political foundation, the Friedrich Naumann Foundation for Freedom, for members of various political parties in the Western Balkans. 

 

 

                                 

*Participating in a study visit to the European Union institutions and conducting research on Serbia’s access to the EU

 

STRENGTHENING DEMOCRATIC INSTITUTIONS AND NGO SECTOR 

 

The opportunity to be an intern in the Serbian Parliament was extremely rewarding. I saw how citizens do not have access to information on work of their representatives. Additionally, I realised how important NGOs are in efforts to achieve more efficient, transparent and accountable governance. This had a considerable influence on my decision to pursue a profession in the non-governmental sector, and to work at the Center for Research, Transparency and Accountability in the “Open Parliament Project”. There, my tasks were to provide the general public with information on parliamentary activities, to cooperate with MPs and parliamentary staff members on questions relating to parliamentary openness and oversight, and to promote the utilization of new technologies designed to foster citizens’ participation. 

 

                            

 

 

*As part of the Open Parliament team, organizing celebration of the International Democracy Day on the streets of Belgrade.

 

                         

*Presenting the work of Open Parliament at Belgrade Ignite - event initiated by ISC and USAID Mission to Serbia for its partner organisations. 

I fight for democratic institutions, the protection of human rights, holding politician to account, and the strengthening of the NGO sector, because I know what it is like to live in a state where democratic values do not exist. I advocate for developing institutions’ and political parties’ capacities in public policy, because I know how dangerous arbitrary decision-making processes dominated by a few individuals can be. I support youth organizations, because I know what it feels like to live in a place where the youth have no hope for a brighter future. 

 

I believe that I can make an even greater contribution to the world in the future. This Masters degree is an important step on my professional path and I can only move forward with your support!

 

                            

                                        Thank you for your effort and contribution! 

                                           Only together can we make a difference!

story:
Join us in changing lives. Cloud Peak helps students from low-income families go to top colleges, graduate with the lowest debt possible, and sometimes graduate with no debt at all. 

·  In 2014-2015, all 16 Cloud Peak students were offered admission to a top college.

·  The average family income was under $30,000 per year.

·  The average scholarship and financial aid for each student was more than $228,000 over four years, or more than $3.3 million total.

Why we need your donation. Cloud Peak pays all expenses for the college application process. Your donation will fund the 20 students we work with this fall. 

Cloud Peak is staffed by volunteers. We need to raise $1200 per student to pay for our costs. We pay for test prep books and provide our test coaching, and pay test fees that aren’t covered by fee waivers. We transmit the test scores to colleges. We pay for some application fees that can’t be waived. We will assist with other expenses when strictly necessary on a case by case basis, like helping a student pay part of the cost of a visit to a college or an interview.  Additionally, we have a budget to pay for winter clothing and linens for students who can’t afford those items when they start their first year of college.  We’d like to give each student a laptop computer, but we’re not there yet.

If we raise more than $25,000, we will use that money for next year’s students and to expand Cloud Peak to reach our eventual goal of serving 200 students per year.

What we do. We work with high achieving students from low-income families and help them through the college admission process.

We provide free, one-to-one coaching through weekly meetings so that every Cloud Peak student succeeds in the college application process. We help our students complete eight to twelve applications. This coaching also focuses on improving standardized test scores on the SAT, ACT, and SAT Subject Tests. We also provide intensive writing instruction for the application essays with a team of volunteer writing mentors who have worked or currently work as professional writers or teachers. We educate students and their families about the opportunities available at the best colleges in the country and help students decide where they will apply.  We do not provide scholarships, but assist students in obtaining the best scholarships and financial aid available.

Cloud Peak coaches over the telephone and Internet, so we can work with students living anywhere in the United States. Our students for 2016 live in Lee County, Collier County, and Palm Beach County, Florida; Brooklyn, New York, and Newark, New Jersey. We want to serve more students in those cities and towns, as well as students in new places.

Success in admissions. Last year, sixteen Cloud Peak students applied to college. All sixteen received offers of admission to top colleges and universities, including Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Emory, Johns Hopkins, M.I.T., Princeton, Stanford, the University of Florida, and Amherst, Bryn Mawr, Barnard, Colgate, Grinnell, Harvey Mudd, Macalester, Middlebury, Olin, and Swarthmore.

Successful track record in college. Cloud Peak began with one student in 2009 who now works as a computer professional after completing a computer science degree at Swarthmore. Every student who has elected to attend a selective private college remains in college or has graduated. We have worked with more than 70 students, including 20 students who are applying to college this year.

How do we find students? We establish ongoing relationships with teachers and guidance counselors in high schools that serve low-income students. These professionals help us select talented and ambitious students.

The main challenges and obstacles for Cloud Peak. There’s a vast pool of talented students from low-income families who are highly qualified for admission to the best colleges in the country. They often do not know about the opportunities, or they don’t know how to get there by themselves. Cloud Peak’s mission is to identify these students and get them into top colleges.

Please contribute to help us achieve our mission. Even if you cannot contribute, please get the word out! Share what we do on your social media networks and by using the Indiegogo share tools. Got to our website: www.cloudpeak.org, or like our Facebook page at Cloud Peak Project, Inc.



For Florida residents:  A COPY OF THE OFFICIAL REGISTRATION AND FINANCIAL INFORMATION MAY BE OBTAINED FROM THE DIVISION OF CONSUMER SERVICES BY CALLING TOLL-FREE 1-800-435-7352 WITHIN THE STATE OR THE WEBSITE AT WWW.800HELPFLA.COM. REGISTRATION DOES NOT IMPLY ENDORSEMENT, APPROVAL, OR RECOMMENDATION BY THE STATE.

next year’s students and to expand Cloud Peak to reach our eventual goal of
serving 200 students per year.
What we do. We
work with high achieving students from low-income families and help them
through the college admission process. 
We provide free, one-to-one coaching through weekly meetings
so that every Cloud Peak student succeeds in the college application process. We
help our students complete eight to twelve applications. This coaching also
focuses on improving standardized test scores on the SAT, ACT, and SAT Subject
Tests. We also provide intensive writing instruction for the application essays
with a team of volunteer writing mentors who have worked or currently work as
professional writers or teachers. We educate students and their families about
the opportunities available at the best colleges in the country and help
students decide where they will apply. 
We do not provide scholarships, but assist students in obtaining the
best scholarships and financial aid available.
Cloud Peak coaches over the telephone and Internet, so we
can work with students living anywhere in the United States. Our students for
2016 live in Lee County, Collier County, and Palm Beach County, Florida;
Brooklyn, New York, and Newark, New Jersey. We want to serve more students in
those cities and towns, as well as students in new places.
Success in
admissions. Last year, sixteen Cloud Peak students applied to college. All
sixteen received offers of admission to top colleges and universities,
including Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Emory, Johns Hopkins, M.I.T.,
Princeton, Stanford, the University of Florida, and Amherst, Bryn Mawr, Barnard,
Colgate, Grinnell, Harvey Mudd, Macalester, Middlebury, Olin, and Swarthmore.
Successful track
record in college. Cloud Peak began with one student in 2009 who now works
as a computer professional after completing a computer science degree at
Swarthmore. Every student who has elected to attend a selective private college
remains in college or has graduated. We have worked with more than 70 students,
including 20 students who are applying to college this year.
How do we find
students? We establish ongoing relationships with teachers and guidance
counselors in high schools that serve low-income students. These professionals
help us select talented and ambitious students.
The main challenges
and obstacles for Cloud Peak. There’s a vast pool of talented students from
low-income families who are highly qualified for admission to the best colleges
in the country. They often do not know about the opportunities, or they don’t
know how to get there by themselves. Cloud Peak’s mission is to identify these
students and get them into top colleges.
Please contribute to help us achieve our mission. Even if
you cannot contribute, please get the word out! Share what we do on your social
media networks and by using the Indiegogo share tools. Got to our website: www.cloudpeak.org, or like our Facebook
page at Cloud Peak Project, Inc.
For Florida
residents:  A COPY OF THE OFFICIAL
REGISTRATION AND FINANCIAL INFORMATION MAY BE OBTAINED FROM THE DIVISION OF
CONSUMER SERVICES BY CALLING TOLL-FREE 1-800-435-7352 WITHIN THE STATE OR THE
WEBSITE AT WWW.800HELPFLA.COM. REGISTRATION DOES NOT IMPLY ENDORSEMENT,
APPROVAL, OR RECOMMENDATION BY THE STATE.

story:
My Work with The Village Education Project
 
I am raising money to spend this summer teaching English in rural Ecuador with The Village Education Project (VEP).
 
The Village Education Project is a non-profit that provides a comprehensive education program for students in the rural highlands outside of Otavalo, Ecuador.  Because of the schools' matriculation fees and the high cost of uniforms and school books, only 1 in 10 students in the impoverished rural areas of Ecuador receive a high school education. VEP provides full scholarships for students in the villages they work in so those students can attend high school for free. But this is not enough.  By the time they are ready to attend high school, most of these students are behind in their studies.  
 
That's where us volunteers come in.  Each year, volunteers come from across the United States to catch the students up in the areas where they need it the most: English, math, and computer skills.  The volunteers are led by Ecuadorian educators on the ground, so the lessons that the volunteers give are consistent with what the students will learn when they start high school.
 
Volunteers also help VEP fund the students' scholarships.  Each volunteer is required to raise a minimum of $500.  100% of this money goes to paying for the students to attend high school.  Because it only costs about $200 to send one student to school per year, just by going to Ecuador, I will make it possible for almost three students to go to school.  
 
In addition to the $500 I need for this scholarship, I need to raise money for my flight and luggage ($1,300), my living expenses ($1,050) and out of the country medical Insurance for two months ($84). I was awarded a Community Service Scholarship when I attended Oberlin College that gives a living stipend. This will cover $2,000 of the cost (YAAAYY!), which helps me a lot, but I'm still in need of your help!
 
The total minimum amount that I need for the trip is:
500+1300+1050+84= 2934
2934-2000= 934


This site charges 4% if I reach my goal so the magic number is $973.

 
If I exceed my goal, I can use that as means to fund other things I need while in Ecuador, in addition to donating that money to VEP to help even more students go to high school. 
 
Other Ways to Help!
  • Tell everyone you know about my campaign and about the work I'll be doing in Ecuador
  • Don't forget to utilize the many different ways to share my page.

Remember, every little bit counts!! I thank you for whatever you are able to give. =]

story:
Hi my name is Robin. I’d like to introduce you to my son Chris. My son Chris is 10 years old, bright, inquisitive and imaginative. He loves to create and make objects out of paper, aluminum foil, tape and other found objects. Chris was born with severe asthma and multiple food allergies. 

He is on a daily dose of 4 medicines to control his asthma. Chris is allergic to dairy, eggs, wheat, beef, pork, seafood, nuts, tomatoes, hummus and several other foods. With all of his food allergies he is not allowed to dine out. At times we will test a different food from his daily regiment but only when we are close to a hospital.

Even though he has gone through so much he approaches every day like it is the best day in the world. He is a loving boy with a warm heart and ready smile.  At the end of camp this year he won the award for the being the most energetic. That’s my baby.

In addition to his asthma and allergies, Chris, has over the years has shown learning and developmental issues.  He could not keep up with the other children in his class. Even though he is bright and can articulate complex scientific theories very eloquently, he is statistically below average in reading , writing, and spelling.

After years of frustration with finding the right educational setting for my son I was able to get him enrolled in a Special Needs School. For the first time with the help of this school, my son is beginning to thrive.  He is happy, less frustrated and learning.  At his Special Needs School he gets specialized attention that focuses on turning his weaknesses into strengths.  The class size is no more than 10 students to four teachers. I was able to enroll him in this school, but tuition is $40,000.  Fortunately, his school offered and I was able to get Chris a $28,000 scholarship , but the rest I have to pay out of pocket.

I am unable to afford the bill. I am currently behind, due to daily expenses like Chris’ medicines and specialty foods. I work full time and have sought every possible avenue to fill the gap to keep my son enrolled. I’ve contacted the department of education and local government agencies as well.

 It has been a struggle and the last thing I wanted to do was ask for help.  However, this is not about me.  It’s about my son, Chris who deserves every opportunity to ensure that he becomes a proud and productive member of our society. So with pride down and faith up, I ask for your help in the continuing struggle to keep Chris in the only educational institution that has been able to help him.

Even if we only receive a portion of my goal it will still help defray cost and help me manage his tuition and also show his school that I am doing everything possible to support my son. If you are unable to donate, then please pass this message on to your network. I am thankful for any help that my son may receive. If you cannot donate money but have suggestions on how to obtain, grants, scholarships and other funding, please email me at Taiiji12@gmail.com.

I look forward to my son making a change in the world. He is always building planes, and pulley systems, it is amazing. I know that with the right resources he will do something special.

I will never give up on my son; I will never stop fighting for him. Won’t you please help?

Thank you,

 Robin

story:
Hilltop Adventist School is grade 1-8 and based on Christian values and excellent learning opportunities.  We are located in Twin Falls, Idaho, a nonprofit organization dedicated to preparing students for a useful and joy-filled life. We work to foster friendship with God, whole person development, Bible-based values, and selfless service in accordance with the Seventh-day Adventist mission to the world. Seven students were sponsored last year. Please help us double the number of students sponsored for this new school year.

This school is run like a mission school where contributions from dedicated people pay for the cost of operating the school.  This allows us to accept worthy children who otherwise could not attend a quality private school, where they can receive individualized help with learning activities. Please join our team in supporting Christian Education that prepares children to serve as the leaders of tomorrow, as well as ambassadors for the Kingdom of God. Our new school year begins in August 2013.  Help us increase enrollment for the new year. Please make your tax deductable contribution now. Thank you very much and may God bless you!

story:
My dear community of family members, friends, colleagues, sistahs, co-workers and fellow community activists.

In May, 2013, I will embark upon a journey that I have been planning and preparing for my entire life. I have been accepted into a doctoral (Ph.D.) program in Clinical Social Work at Smith College in Northampton, MA. It feels like a dream!

Many of you already know that I have dedicated my life and my career to ensuring access to health/mental health services for historically marginalized and disenfranchised people, many of whom come from communities of color and who, without such support, would never receive the care that they rightfully deserve.

I have been honored by being accepted into this program, which will allow me to further my education and training to continue to serve as an advocate, mentor, leader, role model, therapist and woman warrior to continue the fight for equality in health and mental health service delivery.

As a long-time social worker and therapist, I have reaped the benefits of being rich in empathy and compassion for others, rich in friendship, rich in spirit, rich in community, yet not rich with money. For my goal to be realized, I turn to my broader community and ask for your help.

When I first decided to do this ask of my community, I found myself filled with shame and embarrassment at the thought that I couldn't "do this myself." After speaking with a close friend, however, she assured me that people "want to help those who help themselves, and who dedicate their lives to helping others." This is exactly who I am, what I represent and what I plan to do with my degree.

This educational opportunity allows me to not only share my own voice, but to continue to work toward the empowerment of the voiceless, and to bring their stories to the table.

For those of you who know me personally, you know that I am a representative of numerous historically oppressed populations myself. I am African-American, I am a woman, I am a lesbian, I am a child of divorce, I am a formerly obese person, and I am also the daughter and sister of incarcerated African-American males. Fortunately, I am also the daughter of a UC Berkeley graduate, who long ago planted the seeds of education in my heart and mind and instilled in me the value of "each one teach one."

I cannot express enough how much your contribution toward my education will mean to me. You will not only be helping me to achieve my dream, you will be helping me to help others achieve theirs.

For me, the actual dollar amount of your contribution isn't what is significant. What matters to me most is the loving support of my community.....of people who are willing to step up for something that they see as a worthy cause, to say "yes" to education, to personal, emotional and spiritual growth and to the empowerment of others. 

What I'm hoping to receive through this campaign is support toward the almost $30,000 per year tuition and dorm fees that this endeavor will cost.....the travel expense to and from Massachusetts, the upgraded technology that is needed, the books, food, coin laundry, general transportation, and maybe, just maybe, an occasional cup of coffee for those all-nighters!! Going to school is downright expensive!!

Many of you are probably already screaming right now, "WHAT!!! IS SHE CRAZY??" The answer is absolutely YES! I'm just crazy enough to think that I can be accepted into a private institution of higher learning and that with the support of my community, we can make it happen.

Your contribution will ABSOLUTELY make a difference......no matter how small! And, if by chance you are not able to help financially at this time, there are other ways that you can help:

  • You can get the word out to your friends and make some noise about my campaign
  • Share the website with them, tell them my story and remind them to share it with others
  • Post the link on your social networks so that others who may be interested in helping can find the campaign
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to Spread The Word to others!!

And that’s all there is to it.

I thank each and every one of you, from the bottom of my heart, for your contribution. Your support truly means the world to me, and will allow me to not only fulfill my dream, it will continue to allow me to offer the highest level of care and support to the children, adults and families that I am committed to serving.

Peace and Blessings to you all!

 

Nichole

 

"The most satisfying thing in life is to have been able to give a large part of one's self to others.      - Pierre Teilhard de Chardin

You can get the word out to your friends and make some noise about my campaign
Share the website with them, tell them my story and remind them to share it with others
Post the link on your social networks so that others who may be interested in helping can find the campaign
Use the Indiegogo share tools to Spread The Word to others!!


And that’s all there is to it.
I thank each and every one of you, from the bottom of my heart, for your contribution. Your support truly means the world to me, and will allow me to not only fulfill my dream, it will continue to allow me to offer the highest level of care and support to the children, adults and families that I am committed to serving.
Peace and Blessings to you all!
 
Nichole
 
"The most satisfying thing in life is to have been able to give a large part of one's self to others.      - Pierre Teilhard de Chardin

story:
**UPDATE**

I've exceeded my original goal of $500 substantially. I initially set that goal because I wasn't sure how good of a route this would be to raise funds, and I wanted to be realistic. However, after seeing the success of fundraising for this project through IndieGoGo, I decided to raise all of the money I need here.

For the sake of transparency, I've created a Google Doc with all of the financial information surrounding this project. I've also opened up comments on it so anyone can comment with questions, concerns, and ideas.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1nOB9P4tCAkQNlnoLp_O-ZSBN84Bv1WWtt2Qazb3OzYs/edit

Short Summary

I've been sewing since I was 7 years old, and I've been interested in international development since I was a teenager. I discovered an organization called Empower Women and Africa and found that they asked donors to make reusable cloth menstrual pads to give to schoolgirls in Africa. I thought this would be a perfect project for me. But I've discovered that it is costing more money than I can personally invest, which is why I need your help.

What We Need & What You Get

I need $500 to make 200 Empowerment Kits. An Empowerment Kit contains 3 resuable cloth menstrual pads, 9 liners, a cotton storage bag, a pair of underwear, safety pins, and a plastic zip top bag. The supplies I purchase for the sewing portion of this project are flannel, PUL, thread, metal snaps, cotton, and twill tape. With an investment of $500, I'll be able to buy many of these in bulk.

With a donation of $20, you'll receive a handmade cosmetics bag.

The Impact

Research has shown us that resources for education, particularly education for girls, is the best investment we can make in the developing world. Education creates sustainable change and growth in the human economy. Many girls are unable to attend school for a week out of every month because they don't have access to menstrual products, which often ultimately leads to them dropping out early. The one simple task of supplying them with these products keeps them in school.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, share my page through Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Pinterest, Email, text message, carrier pigeon, whatever you can. Help me get the word out to as many people as possible so I can reach my goal of $500.

story:
A Very Simple Theory

"The people in conflicts, like Northern Ireland or in Israel and Palestine, had the characteristics of addicts," says O'Malley. "I developed a very simple theory, that just as AA works in the principle that one alcoholic is in the best position to help another, that one divided society is in the best position to help another."

http://www.wbur.org/radioboston/2016/05/13/peacemaker-documentary

What if YOU could impact peace?

Cities around the globe are struggling with conflict – in many cases this conflict is deeply rooted and underlies the day-to-day existence of the people who live there.

People like you and me are working now to help cities emerge from this conflict.  You can be a part of this people-powered work today.

Working to Change the World

Padraig O’Malley, the subject of the documentary “The Peacemaker,” has selflessly dedicated his life to working for peace and reconciliation. 

In 2009, Padraig piloted a forum based on the principle that societies in conflict are in the best position to help each other.  The Forum for Cities in Transition (FCT) brings divided cities together to make progress for peace.  It is not a conference where people come just to listen –rather, it is a very active forum where  mayors, clergy, and people working in non-governmental organizations (NGO’s) work together on tangible objectives.

Since 2009, a different participating city has hosted FCT each year. Last year, the Forum did not take place due to the challenges inherent in planning a large conference in a conflict-ridden city.

Passion and Determination

In 2011, Rob Goodwin & Julie Kiernan had an idea to create a global center where people can connect, educate & inspire. 

In 2014, that idea started to become reality when they founded Stone & Compass and then in the fall of 2015 they purchased a property in Stolat, Bulgaria, in the foothills of the Balkan Mountains, and have worked hard to create a 1500-acre retreat center.


Making connections

Chance led to an opportunity when Rob met Padraig in 2015.  Rob and Julie saw how Padraig’s work aligned with their ultimate goal of creating a more peaceful world through human-to-human exchange and cross-cultural understanding. Rob, Julie & Padraig forged a partnership in June of 2016 that would give FCT a permanent home at the Stone and Compass Center, beginning with the 2017 forum.

It quickly became clear the October 2016 forum needed a home, too, and Stone & Compass offered to host with only three months to prepare.  They knew it would be a lot of work, but they believed it could be done.  As Rob likes to say: “Onward!”

What We Need & What You Get

We have raised two-thirds of the funding needed, but we still need $20,000 for translators, translating equipment, infrastructure, housing and airfare for participants who cannot afford to purchase their own. We have a very short time to bridge our funding gap.

You get the satisfaction of knowing you have contributed to creating peace in the world, as well as some great perks ranging from beautiful photographs of Bulgaria to a trip with Stone & Compass in 2017!

All proceeds (that means 100%!) collected will support the 2016 Forum.  (Any funds beyond what we need for this year will go toward the cost of hosting the 2017 Forum.)

Your support enables Padraig and the delegates to come to the forum to do this effective peacekeeping work now & in the future.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with others!

Visit Stone and Compass for information about our tours that help support FCT and our other philanthropic work.

Thank you for being a PEACE of the puzzle!
story_txt:
A Very Simple Theory"The people in conflicts, like
Northern Ireland or in Israel and Palestine, had the characteristics of addicts,"
says O'Malley. "I developed a very simple theory, that just as AA works in
the principle that one alcoholic is in the best position to help another, that
one divided society is in the best position to help another." http://www.wbur.org/radioboston/2016/05/13/peacemaker-documentaryWhat if YOU could
impact peace?Cities around the
globe are struggling with conflict – in many cases this conflict is deeply
rooted and underlies the day-to-day existence of the people who live there. 
People like you and me
are working now to help cities emerge from this conflict.  You can be a part of this people-powered work
today.
Working to Change the
World
Padraig O’Malley, the
subject of the documentary “The Peacemaker,” has selflessly dedicated his life
to working for peace and reconciliation.  
In 2009, Padraig piloted
a forum based on the principle that societies in conflict are in the best
position to help each other.  The Forum for Cities in Transition (FCT) brings divided cities together to make progress
for peace.  It is not a conference where
people come just to listen –rather, it is a very active forum where  mayors, clergy, and people working in
non-governmental organizations (NGO’s) work together on tangible objectives.
Since 2009, a
different participating city has hosted FCT each year. Last year, the Forum did not take place due to
the challenges inherent in planning a large conference in a conflict-ridden
city.Passion and DeterminationIn 2011, Rob Goodwin
& Julie Kiernan had an idea to create a global center where people can
connect, educate & inspire.  In 2014,
that idea started to become reality when they founded Stone & Compass and then in the fall of 2015 they purchased a property in Stolat, Bulgaria, in the foothills of the Balkan Mountains, and have worked hard to create a 1500-acre retreat center.Making connectionsChance led to an
opportunity when Rob met Padraig in 2015. 
Rob and Julie saw how Padraig’s work aligned with their ultimate goal of
creating a more peaceful world through human-to-human exchange and cross-cultural
understanding.
Rob, Julie & Padraig
forged a partnership in June of 2016 that would give FCT a permanent home at
the Stone and Compass Center, beginning with the 2017 forum. It quickly became
clear the October 2016 forum needed a home, too, and Stone & Compass
offered to host with only three months to prepare.  They knew it would be a lot of work, but they
believed it could be done.  As Rob likes
to say: “Onward!”
What We Need &
What You Get
We have raised
two-thirds of the funding needed, but we still need $20,000 for translators, translating
equipment, infrastructure, housing and airfare for participants who cannot afford to purchase their own.
We have a very short time to bridge our
funding gap.
You get the satisfaction
of knowing you have contributed to creating peace in the world, as well as some
great perks ranging from beautiful photographs of Bulgaria to a trip with Stone
& Compass in 2017!
All proceeds (that means
100%!) collected will support the 2016 Forum. 
(Any funds beyond what we need for this year will go toward the cost of
hosting the 2017 Forum.)
Your support enables
Padraig and the delegates to come to the forum to do this effective peacekeeping work
now & in the future.
Other Ways You Can
Help
Please share this
campaign with others!
Visit Stone and Compass
for information about our tours that help support FCT and our other philanthropic work.
Thank you for being a
PEACE of the puzzle!

story:
Short Summary

Many remedial college students and GED candidates struggle to make ends meet, and simply cannot afford to hire a private tutor. For many of these students, the remedial classroom is overcrowded and instructors are overextended. Consequently, many have to retake the same remedial classes, sometimes two or three times, often leading to crippling student debt.

I've taught and tutored mathematics and computer science for over a decade. I recently left my teaching positions at City University of New York to focus on expanding my private tutoring business. As part of this expansion, I intend to offer students in need an opportunity to take a remedial class, in a small classroom setting of no more than 10 students at a time, at no charge to the student.

What We Need

Since textbooks are outrageously expensive, I will be generating all necessary course materials and providing them to the students at no charge. I need funding to cover the cost of printing, supplies, and possibly space.

I also need funding to cover my meager cost of living as I work on this project. My partner is employed full-time, but my decision to leave my job to work on this has meant a decrease in our income. That will change as my business grows, and the work I'm doing to expand my business should help cover the cost of this project in the long run. However, Summer is a difficult time for private tutors, and your donation will help get this project going sooner rather than later.

The Impact

You will be providing a low-income student with a valuable opportunity they wouldn't be able to afford otherwise. In this economy, the need for free, quality remedial math education is great. This is a way to make a real, positive impact in the life of those who need it.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Check out my professional website, ITERAN.
  • Follow me on Facebook and/or Google+.
  • Tell your friends, especially if you are in the New York City area and know someone who might benefit from this project.

story:
What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $10,000.00 USD to supplement scholarships for all qualifying youth to attend the 4 week program and continue working with them into the school year.

Check out the tiered perks offered at each donor level.

All contributed funds will go towards programming, no matter how much we raise.

Youth will:

1) be trained and mentored by professional Hip Hop element artists  (DJ Bounce of Scratch DJ Academy, MECCAakaGRIMO, Newcre and TREK6)

2) learn the 4 main artistic elements of Hip Hop (DJ, MC, Bboy/Bgirl and Urban Art) 

3) participate in personal/professional development master classes facilitated by industry leaders. Sessions will cover leadership, entrepreneurship, financial literacy, project planning and more

4) earn community service hours for participation in service learning projects 

5) hone academic, service, leadership and entrepreneurial skills through project-based learning experiences (based on the Model Eliciting Activities framework)

6) qualify for college scholarships, internships and other exclusive opportunities including POSSE, PATH Internship Program and PATH Jr. Fellows

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to give, please share this giving opportunity with your personal and professional network.

If you are interested in volunteering your time, please fill out a volunteer registration form:  http://www.pathtohiphop.org/youth/volunteer/

All donations to PATH: Preserving, Archiving & Teaching Hiphop, Inc. are tax deductible. For more info. about tax deductible donations, send inquiries to: info@pathtohiphop.org.   Subject: Tax Deductible Donation

story:
Statistics show many adults over the age of 15 read at or below a 4th-grade level, increasing high school dropout rates, lowering employment and salary figures, and contributing to incarceration rates.

The I AM Project engages young adults who are reading below grade level in an effort to boost test scores and empower students with valuable life skills.

Our innovative curriculum includes workshops, mentorships, laser coaching sessions, and a one-of-a-kind creative writing component that will result in a published anthology of student work.

We are finalizing our curriculum and preparing to launch this fall. Once we launch, we will need instructors, mentors, meeting spaces, printed materials, and other project-specific materials as the curriculum requires (ie poster board, scissors, glue sticks, and magazines for vision boards). We also need operational funds for promoting the program and keeping a minimal staff who are working tirelessly to build a solid foundation and grow the organization at an accelerated pace.

The sooner we get funded, the sooner we will be able to conduct our pilot program and make an impact. We can't afford to wait, so we are reaching out to you to help with funding and practical assistance.

In return, you play a valuable role in impacting your community and the next generation. You'll see, some of the specific perks you can get here include sponsoring a student; nabbing a copy of our founder, Mike McGrew's, new self-help book, Designer Relationships; and becoming part of the Authors Rock movement with our bold t-shirts.

The impact is immeasurable. For the individual students, it can change the trajectory of their lives. For their families and friends, it creates greater stability and happiness, and continued investment in the community. And for everyone, it creates a stronger, more vibrant economy and a richer life.

In addition to contributing to The I AM Project's campaign, we need your help:

  • Follow The I AM Project on Facebook, Twitter, and in ournewsletter
  • Contact us to see what in-kind donations we are looking for
  • Flex your network! Help us connect with civic-minded businesspeople, community leaders, social and political advocates, and everyone who has a stake in bettering our youth (hint: that's everyone!)

The I AM Project for Literacy is awaiting confirmation of our nonprofit status from the IRS. Until then, we are operating under the fiscal sponsorship of the ComeUnity Arts organization - a Los Angeles-based 501(c)3.

Thank you so much for your support. We cannot make this change without you!

story:
Teddy Bear Tea is, simply put, magic. 

The hotel in which the Teddy Bear Tea is held is breathtaking. The lobby is draped in shining, sparkling lights, dangling crystals, and dozens of elaborately decorated trees. The tea ballroom looks like a scene from Santa's Workshop. Santa, Mrs. Claus, Rudolph, and other characters move throughout the tables as tea-goers in fancy dresses enjoy bottomless glasses of hot chocolate and delicious pastries. As full and happy little girls file out of the ballroom, they are handed a teddy bear as a memento. Something they can look at to help them remember this wonderful day. 

 

 

Your donation would be giving my girls an experience they'll never forget. 

Being able to attend a Teddy Bear Tea is something we couldn't do without the help of others! If you have it in your hearts to donate, my girls and I would greatly appreciate it.

story:
WHAT IF YOU COULDN'T GO TO COLLEGE?

Our goal is to raise $10,000 in order to continue providing underrepresented students with standardized test preparation courses. Our program focuses on finding students who would otherwise be unable to attend test prep courses and providing them with the tools they need to succeed. Students who have completed our program have gone on to receive college acceptance letters from many prestigious universities. Such a high rate of acceptance would have been impossible without our College Readiness Program as result of our success, we are expanding the program, but we need your help. Every student deserves to experience success, regardless of their socioeconomic status.

(All information obtained from Yahoo! News)

Who are we?

Gateway Educational Services was established in 2009 by educators, business professionals, and community leaders passionate about changing access to education and the ways in which students learn. We are Santa Barbara’s only non-profit college prep learning center.

What is the money going towards?

  • What we raise will go towards funding our College Readiness Program, allowing us to focus on preparing underrepresented students for standardized exams necessary for acceptance into college. Students will receive over 60 hours of one to one tutoring, help with essay writing, and math. The program includes mentoring and help with the college application process. 
  • The funds will provide scholarships for students who excel in school but who may not be able to afford standardized test prep. Our next class begins June 21st and we have 8 students waiting and wanting to be accepted into the program.          

The Impact

100% of our students have been accepted to awesome colleges! 

Maria completed our program last year. She was accepted by: University of La Verne, St. Mary's College, Westmont, UC Santa Cruz, CSU Channel Islands, & Cal Lutheran!

Sandra completed our program last year. She was accepted by: Chapman University, University of San Francisco, Gonzaga, San Francisco State University, Santa Clara, Loyola Marymount University, Cal Lutheran!

The History

  • In 2012, we were able to help 3 students. They all received acceptance letters from their top-choice universities.

  • In 2013, 4 students completed our SAT/ACT Intensive Program and received a total of 15 acceptance letters. 
  • We currently have 6 students enrolled with another 8 wanting to start on June 21st! Please help make that happen.

    For more information about us:
    Follow us on Twitter!
    Like us on Facebook!
    Visit our Website!

story:
Wow!! We've raised all of Nobert's funds and more in less than a week!  Thank you so much to everyone who contributed!!!  

Though the campaign is still open for another month, I am hoping to get the $524.80 tuition into his school account within the next few weeks and will post confirmation that it has been paid when that I receive the receipt from the teachers. 

The extra money that we have raised on top of the fees will be transferred to Nobert to pay for uniform updates, school supplies, transportation, and other incidentals.    

On that note, I didn't realize we would raise this money so quickly - I shouldn't left the campaign open for so long and it is not possible to cancel it.  At this point, we don't need any more donations as I don't want to pay his tuition for next year in advance because the bookkeeping/bureaucracy can be a bit of a hassle from far away.  It would be more logistically easier just to raise money again next year, so you can contribute then if you missed out this time around!  I repeat: they are much appreciated but we don't need any more donations to this campaign!

 I will continue to update this space with a message from Nobert once he has heard the great news, and with the confirmation of receipt of funds from the school once it is all paid up.  Asanteni sana!!!


Who is Nobert? 

Nobert is a wonderful young man from Mosoriot, a small town in the beautiful Rift Valley, who needs our help to pay for his secondary schooling. I've gotten to know and love Nobert during my multiple stays with a family in Kenya over the past two and a half years. Nobert lived with the family since he was about eight years old, when his own mother could no longer afford to take care of him. In return for their generosity, Nobert happily helped out around their home before and after his day at school.

While primary education is free in Kenya, students must pay fees to attend secondary school. In 2012, Nobert qualified to attend an excellent provincial-level boarding school. Unfortunately, that same year, Nobert's mother passed away from an illness. I went to visit him when I heard the news. During that difficult time, Nobert expressed a concern no child should have to face - with no living parents, how would he pay for his school fees? 

With the help of friends and family last year, we were able to pay for Nobert's Form 1 school year. I visited Moi Highschool in July and met with his teachers, who spoke fondly of him and thanked me as his 'sponsor.' In addition to his studies, he participates competitively in both music and volleyball. He also volunteers at the school's library - he loves to read and is always asking me to bring more novels for him to devour! Nobert is also very active in his Church.  

Nobert is the sweetest kid I have ever met. He is full of life and love for the people in it, even in the face of hardship. These things aside, everyone deserves to be able to go to school. Please consider contributing anything you can for Nobert so he can continue his secondary education! 

What We Need

Pictured below is a breakdown of the fees necessary to attend Moi High School for the year of 2014. The equivalent is about 525 CAD, plus the cost of wiring the money to him. As a full-time Masters student I can't cover the full cost of this myself. Any contribution would be much appreciated! 

Anything extra we might raise will be sent to cover the cost of his transportation to his hometown to see his younger siblings (whom he can't afford to visit often) and to incidentals like fixing up his school uniform and buying new school supplies. :)

The Impact

Nobert is eager to learn and values his schooling. Furthermore, attending a provincial school has afforded him opportunities not only to study, but to build networks of friendship and support with students from all over the country through extracurricular activities and the boarding lifestyle. I believe this is important in any child's life, and particularly for a young man like Nobert who has had a complicated family life. 

Furthermore, if you've met Nobert, you will know that his education will be of value to more than just him. Someone so full of love for the people around him will surely use his education to give back to the communities he is part of! 

I will post updates from Nobert so that you can personally see his progress in school and know that your money is going to a great cause. He is currently awaiting results of his final examinations from Form 1, which I will post here. I'm going to send Nobert the link to this page and am certain that there will be a BIG ASANTE SANA (Kiswahili for 'thank you') for all of you that I will post here!!!

Asante sana! Thank you so much!
