story:
THE PROBLEM:

The problem of teenagers secretly suffering with an addiction to pornography is far larger than most people know. There are several programs and organizations set up to help adults overcome this issue but currently teens are completely left in the dark. 

We at Fight the New Drug (FTND) continue to receive hundreds of emails from desperate teens looking for help. Some got into it because they just didn’t know any better and others thought they could control their addiction and are now desperate for a way out. 

Here are a just a few examples of the many emails we receive:

  • "My name is Carllee, I’m a female, and 16 years old. I’ve been addicted to porn and masturbating since I was 12 years old. I don’t even remember how I started it, all I know is I can’t quit. I have no idea what to do. I feel helpless and miserable. I feel like dirt and sometimes I feel like I deserve to go to hell. I try to quit all the time but then I get that weird feeling and I just have to do it. I wish this didn’t cost because I would definitely do it. I really need really bad. Someone please help me.”    -Carllee 
  • “Im nearly 16 years old. I have been addicted to pornography since I was 10. I have been addicted to masturbation since I was 13. Im sick of this #%$@. I NEED HELP!”    -Elan 
  • “I am 11 and I just can’t seem to stop I get so frustrated when I do it I get mad right now.”    -Caleb 

They come to us looking for help but up until now our approach was strictly education and awareness. We didn’t offer any sort of tangible solution besides education and our resources page – which the majority of resources listed cost money and can’t accept a teenager without parental consent. So… they don’t do anything. They’re stuck. Those teens continue to suffer hoping that it’ll go away. But it doesn't. The more we learn about the brain and addiction the more we are realizing the need for professional help when trying to overcome an addiction to pornography. 

As we see the many emails that come through we’ve been able to identify the top 3 reasons why teens are not getting the help they need. 

  1. Money: Most addiction recovery programs out there cost hundreds and sometimes thousands of dollars.  Even if a teenager had such funds most of the institutions require a credit card, which is completely out of reach for a teen.
  2. Parental Consent: Teens would rather suffer in silence than admit their imperfections to their parents, especially imperfections surrounding such a sensitive topic as pornography.  Most teens that contact us literally believe that their parents will stop loving them and in some cases even physically harm them if they found out.  Of course, those assumptions are most likely inaccurate but given that state of mind it’s understandable why they are unwilling to confront their parents and ask for help.  So they don’t do anything. They’re stuck.  
  3. Relatable: Currently there isn’t an online resource that targets and caters to teens.  Most organizations target the parents because they are the ones with the money and the ones choosing the program.  This is helpful for parents who have caught their child and are forcing them to get help.  But what about the teen that chooses to seek help?  If there isn’t a resource out there that’s speaking and targeting them, they won’t respond.

 

SOLUTION:

Because of the constant cry for help from these young people we knew we had to do something. We needed to figure out a way to eliminate this friction and provide them with a solution today rather than waiting for them to turn 18 and pay for help themselves, or wait until there is a crisis and the damage is already done. 

We are currently in the process of developing a FREE online teen program, FORTIFY: A Step Towards Recovery. This program will not only give professional education but also tools and resources to assist in overcoming an addiction to pornography. FORTIFY will solve the very reasons why teens weren't getting professional help.

  1. Money: Our program will be free.
  2. Parental Consent: They can start the program on their own without parental consent.  However, our goal for the program is to help decrease their fear and anxiety of getting a parent or loved one involved.  We will train them in the most effective ways to address it with their parents/loved ones.  Intervention increases recovery more than any other method. 
  3. Relatable: Research shows that in order for us to be effective with teens you have to be cool first and informative second.  The delivery of the content has to be packaged in a way that will keep their attention and encourage understanding.  That’s why we’re producing short, to-the-point videos that will teach the necessary principles.  These videos will be filled with dynamic graphics, animations, and delivered by a young peer-like individual that will do a far better job of relating than any other authoritative figure. 

 

PROJECT ITEMS AND DEADLINES:

  • Content Development:  Our team of professional therapists and neurologists will finalize the content and script development for the 45 lessons in the program by October 1st, 2012. 
  • FORTIFY Website:  Graphic design, programming, and copywriting for the FORTIFY website is set to be completed on December 15th, 2012.
  • Video/Animation Production:  Once we have the scripts finished and finalized we will then film and create the videos. These videos will need to be very well produced and executed in order to engage young people. We are partnering with professional animators/videographers to complete this project.  The videos and animation deadline is February 1st, 2013.

 

PRIMARY GOALS FOR FORTIFY:

  • Getting a parent or trusted adult involved.
  • Helping them understand addiction and provide the proper steps towards recovery including additional resources and tools.
  • Help them recognize their own addictive triggers and behaviors as well as the pathway out of their addiction.

 

EXPECTED OUTCOMES:

  • Teens will receive adequate education and training to help them fully overcome their addiction to pornography.
  • Their understanding of what addiction is and how it might harm them will sharpen to a level that will influence positive behaviors. 
  • They will comprehend the need for the involvement of a loved one and understand that in order for them to fully recover and stay recovered they will likely require continuous and ongoing effort. 

Measurement is key to the success of this program. Built into the Fortify program will be a rigorous measuring tool that will help us gather the necessary data when assessing the progress of each individual student. This will not only help the student know how they’ve progressed but it will also help us better understand where the program is strong and where it is weak. This data will allow us to modify and adjust the program for continuous improvement. 

 

FUNDING PLAN

This project is already underway. The website and branding is currently being developed. Here are all budget items: 

  • Fortify Website:  The website includes design, programming, forums, measurement and database managements systems.   

Total Cost:  $22,000

  • Content Development:  This includes all scripts and content developed by therapist and neurologist as well as copywriting to transfer complex language to everyday teen language.  This also includes all downloadable tools and resources used through out the program.     

Total Cost:  $24,000

  • Video/Animation Production:  There are a total of 45 videos; each video is roughly 3-5 minutes in length.  37 of the 45 videos will include animation and graphics.  This piece of the project is by far the most time consuming and technical.  We’ve already raised nearly $25,000 for this budget item but need to raise $35,000 to complete.         

Total Cost:  $35,000         

 

WHAT WE NEED FROM YOU!!

The good news is that we have already raised a good portion of the funds needed. All we need from the INDIEGOGO community is $25,000. We need you! With your help we will be able to help tens of thousands of struggling teenagers overcome their addiction to pornography. Join us in this incredible cause. BECOME A FIGHTER!
story_txt:
THE PROBLEM:
The problem of teenagers secretly suffering with an addiction to pornography is far larger than most people know. There are several programs and organizations set up to help adults overcome this issue but currently teens are completely left in the dark. 
We at Fight the New Drug (FTND) continue to receive hundreds of emails from desperate teens looking for help. Some got into it because they just didn’t know any better and others thought they could control their addiction and are now desperate for a way out. 
Here are a just a few examples of the many emails we receive:


"My name is Carllee, I’m a female, and 16 years old. I’ve been addicted to porn and masturbating since I was 12 years old. I don’t even remember how I started it, all I know is I can’t quit. I have no idea what to do. I feel helpless and miserable. I feel like dirt and sometimes I feel like I deserve to go to hell. I try to quit all the time but then I get that weird feeling and I just have to do it. I wish this didn’t cost because I would definitely do it. I really need really bad. Someone please help me.”    -Carllee 


“Im nearly 16 years old. I have been addicted to pornography since I was 10. I have been addicted to masturbation since I was 13. Im sick of this #%$@. I NEED HELP!”    -Elan 


“I am 11 and I just can’t seem to stop I get so frustrated when I do it I get mad right now.”    -Caleb 

They come to us looking for help but up until now our approach was strictly education and awareness. We didn’t offer any sort of tangible solution besides education and our resources page – which the majority of resources listed cost money and can’t accept a teenager without parental consent. So… they don’t do anything. They’re stuck. Those teens continue to suffer hoping that it’ll go away. But it doesn't. The more we learn about the brain and addiction the more we are realizing the need for professional help when trying to overcome an addiction to pornography.

They’re stuck.

FORTIFY will solve the very reasons why teens weren't getting professional help.

Parental Consent: They can start the program on their own without parental consent.  However, our goal for the program is to help decrease their fear and anxiety of getting a parent or loved one involved.  We will train them in the most effective ways to address it with their parents/loved ones.  Intervention increases recovery more than any other method.

PROJECT ITEMS AND DEADLINES:


Content Development:  Our team of professional therapists and neurologists will finalize the content and script development for the 45 lessons in the program by October 1st, 2012. 


FORTIFY Website:  Graphic design, programming, and copywriting for the FORTIFY website is set to be completed on December 15th, 2012.


Video/Animation Production:  Once we have the scripts finished and finalized we will then film and create the videos. These videos will need to be very well produced and executed in order to engage young people. We are partnering with professional animators/videographers to complete this project.  The videos and animation deadline is February 1st, 2013.

story:
It All Started With A Fedora.

 

 

30 years ago I sat in a darkened theater, my eyes glued to the big screen, and was swept away into a world of wonder as “Raiders of the Lost Ark” unfolded in front of me. Like many of my generation I dreamed of donning a fedora, picking up a bullwhip and setting off to confront the unknown. Unfortunately, I decided to set aside my boyhood dreams and follow a rather mundane path in life. Unremarkable grades in college flowed seamlessly into a series of jobs, in sales, IT and the like, but no matter what I did I never felt satisfied. I still wanted my dream.

 

10 years ago I took a chance, packed my bags, booked a ticket to Belize and spent the summer excavating with the Maya Research Program. One summer turned into another, followed soon thereafter by a graduate degree in archaeology, and finally a job doing what I love the most: excavating Maya ruins deep in the jungles of Belize.

 

Over the past decade, with the help of many close colleagues, students, and volunteers, I hav strived to contribute to our understanding of the process and conditions that were present at the fall of the Classic period Maya civilization. While I have never had to evade a cunningly constructed death trap or hold off a sword-wielding fanatic with my trusty bullwhip, I feel that I am living out the dream that I had as a young man.


2012 Marks a new beginning for me and the Maya Research Program. We have not conducted a large scale excavation an a Maya site center since the late 1990's. That will change this year. I will be starting excavations that are projected to last for at least the next 5 years. The site of X'noha is a medium sized city that was once the home for at least 20,000 Maya. The site center is comprised of two main plazas and at least 6 large monumental structures. I will begin excavations on two of these structures this year. We hope to gain insites both on why the city was founded where it is along with what processes led to its abandonment.

 

 

The Impact

The excavations at X'noha will have two real impacts on the world. The first is the basic research that will be gained from the work conducted this summer. One of the great mysteries of the Americas is why the Maya civilization collapsed at the end of the Classic period, around 800 A.D. I have been studying this thoughout my career as an archaeologists and have been able to come to some tentative conclusions. Enviromental degradation caused though jungle clearing and the over use of intensive agricultural practices led to a breakdown in the society. In a nutshell the Maya were no longer able to feed their population. As we enter an uncertain time with our own resources being stretch I see some of the same societal pressures that the Maya faced mirrored in our own world wide society. By studying what happened in the past we can see some of the challenges that our society will face in the future.

 

The second impact that my excavations will have is more immediate. Many of our irreplaceable cultural resouces are being lost and destroyed as jungles throughout Central America are cleared for unsustainable industrial scale farming. Just last year an ancient Maya city similar to the one that I will be excavating was destroyed to when land was cleared to make room for more cattle pastures. My excavations will at least temporarily halt any more clearing of the jungle. This will leave intact not only the city but an irreplaceable habitat that is home to two species of monkey, jaguar and other wild cats, deer, peccary, and numerous small animals. I hope that though a combination of personal appeals and community education, I can halt the clearing of this area and leave it wild and safe for future generations.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Lets be honest, excavations are expensive. While many of the projects undertaken by the Maya Research Program (www.mayaresearchprogram.org) are funded by volunteer contributions, I am starting an large scale excavations that have not been attempted for more than 10 years. I will need funds to pay for everything from wages for our local workers, fuel for our vehicles, to basic tools and supplies. The $5000 that I an trying to raise will not cover all of my expenses, but it will help. I am not asking for any funds to cover my personal expenses, I will cover that myself, but I do need to raise enough funds to cover the excavation expenses at least in part. any funds will help, and the more that I can raise means that my excavations can be more extensive.

 

I am hoping to hire at least 5 workers from the nearby town of San Felipe. This alone will require a capital outlay of $5000. We pay the highest wages for skilled archaeological workers in the area, $20 per worker for eight full weeks. In addition I estimate that that my fuel and vehicle maintenance expenses for the summer will top $1000. I have not even added in the essential materials that an excavation of this scale requires. We Will need tarps to protect the exposed buildings, replacement tools (picks, shovels, buckets, and the like). Treats for my team, everyone likes a cookie break in the morning. An team of 15 people requires numerous small items to stay productive, safe, and in good spirits.

 

About the Maya Research Program

The Maya Research Program has been conducting excavations in Belize for the past 20 years. These excavations include everything from the large monumental structures in the core of the Blue Creek site to the outlying agricultural zones that would have fed a thriving city. Thousands of students from areas all over the world have participated in these excavations.
 
The Maya Research Program is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization and as such all donations made to this campaign are completely tax deductible. If desired a letter to the IRS detailing your donation will be sent to you.

Other Ways You Can Help

(Unleash the DIWO! -- 'Do It With Others' by asking folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Don't forget to remind them about the share tools!)

story:
Support us and check out our updates on:

                                                    

 

What’s Happening:

San Antonio de Rioyos, Mexico

 

Our outreach team has been working with mothers in San Antonio de Rioyos,  a small rural town in Guanajuato, Mexico,  to identify ways to improve their local kindergarten and provide education for the community’s youth.

 

    ““Sometimes, I imagine I am a little girl, and that I have to come here and sit down inside this classroom. It makes me want to cry.”

                                                           ~Doña Adela, grandmother

 

 

These vivacious children come to kindergarten while their parents work in the fields. However, the community does not have the resources to sustain the volunteer teacher, fund books, or buy toys. The cramped classroom lacks water and electricity. Without a stable teacher or proper classroom, the children are mostly illiterate, unable to grasp basic mathematical concepts, and unprepared to continue their education in the nearby towns.

 

IN NUMBERS:

* 1/5 children attend the local kindergarten*
* 85% drop out before completing middle school*

* Virtually NO high school completion*

* 80% of teens cannot find employment*

* Poor educational quality, school fees, transportation costs, bullying, and lack of perceived opportunity are all quoted reasons for discontinuing education*

 

Let’s Break it Down - Where the 11k goes:

   

We have the land, a water source, a teacher, and many eager parents and children. Furthermore, we have partnered with individuals at the American School Foundation of Guadalajara for teacher training and donated curriculum. All we need now is the funding to translate our goals for educational improvement into reality:

 

1) $2,500 Teacher’s Salary

2) $3,500 School Refurbishment

* Larger Kindergarten Classroom * Electricity* Tables and Chairs * On-Site Living Quarters for Teacher * Garden * Soccer Field

3) $2,100 Education Materials

        * Books * Computers * Art supplies* Creative learning puzzles* Sport

Equipment

4) $2,000 Nutrition

        *Healthy breakfast of local bananas, milk, crackers

5) $876 Others

        * Community Engagement projects* IRS Application Fee to become 501-C3

In the case we do not meet full funding, we will postpone the others section.

 

 

 

The Project Details:

 

FTDO will revitalize San Antonio de Rioyos’ kindergarten by focusing on 4 main issues:

 

1) “Bien aprende quien buen maestro tiene”: Teacher Transiency

(The one who learns well is the one who has a good teacher -- popular refrain)

 

    

Currently, the kindergarten cannot recruit and retain its kindergarten teachers. Just this year, the government (CONAFE) sent 4 different teacher volunteers into the community. This leaves students with an insufficient number of class days and eliminates any sense of trust and continuity between young children and their educators. We aim to fix this issue by building a living quarter for the teacher on school grounds and providing a salary to support his/her living expenses. These improvements will ensure lengthier teacher involvement within the community.

 

2) A Place to Learn, a Place to Play: Schoolhouse Refurbishment

         

The current kindergarten made of gray concrete walls and two adjoining desks does not provide a conducive atmosphere for 4-6 year old children to learn, play, and grow. We will revitalize the current classroom by expanding the size to accommodate 25 students, adding electricity, painting the walls a vibrant color to cover the grey concrete, planting a garden, and making a futból field. In so doing, the children will have the learning environment they need to grow into well-rounded individuals.  

 

3) Books, puzzles, and toys, oh my!: Educational Materials

                

The kids are tired of reading the same disintegrating books over and over again. We will provide computers that have educational videos and games, along with new reading books, pens, paper, and arts and crafts supplies. By making learning fun, we aim to improve their literacy rates, basic mathematical concepts, and writing abilities.

 

4) No more rumbling in my tummy: Nutrition

        

The intense poverty in San Antonio de Rioyos is manifested in the community’s lack of access to basic food.  The children come to school without having had breakfast. Although they have a break to go home for lunch, they often remain at school because their parents cannot afford to provide them with an afternoon meal. To shift the kids’ focus from their rumbling tummies to solving “1+1” in the classroom, FTDO will introduce a nutrition program that starts bright and early: we will give kids a healthy breakfast of local milk, bananas, and whole grain crackers.

 

 

 

YOUR IMPACT:  

        


Every donation, big or small, will go exclusively toward the revitalization of the kindergarten in San Antonio de Rioyos.

 

By June 2014, all donations will be matched 5X by Fair Trade Social premiums provided by Fair Trade company Organic Alliance, Inc, so that we can continue the work that you start!

 

 

       

 

 

 

All of your support for this campaign does not only revitalize the community’s kindergarten, but also lays the foundation for our subsequent goal of creating a digital learning and recreation center, elementary, middle and high schools. These multi-phase projects make up La Esquina de la Educación. Together, we can build more than a kindergarten. We can build an entire movement toward quality education for the area.


Furthermore, if you have any questions, or would like to get involved, please do not hesitate to contact us! 

Patricia O’Rourke
Yasamin Soltanianzadeh



 

Who We Are:

We here at the Fair Trade Development Organization (FTDO) are dedicated to improving lives in rural Fair Trade agricultural communities in Latin America. We are a non-profit organization that identifies opportunities to build a better future in remote communities in need of basic health care, schooling, and economic opportunity. After personally working with communities, we harness resources through crowd-funding, donors, partners, and the Fair Trade market to bring those projects to life. With a ‘boots-on-the-ground’ approach, FTDO works directly with communities to identify, plan, and execute social projects for the highest social return with the greatest level of efficiency.

 Please visit us at our website.

 We have the land, a water source, a teacher, and many eager parents and children. Furthermore, we have partnered with individuals at the American School Foundation of Guadalajara for teacher training and donated curriculum. All we need now is the funding to translate our goals for educational improvement into reality:
 
1) $2,500 Teacher’s Salary
2) $3,500 School Refurbishment
* Larger Kindergarten Classroom * Electricity* Tables and Chairs * On-Site Living Quarters for Teacher * Garden * Soccer Field 
3) $2,100 Education Materials
        * Books * Computers * Art supplies* Creative learning puzzles* Sport
Equipment
4) $2,000 Nutrition
        *Healthy breakfast of local bananas, milk, crackers
5) $876 Others
        * Community Engagement projects* IRS Application Fee to become 501-C3
In the case we do not meet full funding, we will postpone the others section.
 
 

 
The Project Details:
 
FTDO will revitalize San Antonio de Rioyos’ kindergarten by focusing on 4 main issues:
 
1) “Bien aprende quien buen maestro tiene”: Teacher Transiency
(The one who learns well is the one who has a good teacher -- popular refrain)
 
     
Currently, the kindergarten cannot recruit and retain its kindergarten teachers. Just this year, the government (CONAFE) sent 4 different teacher volunteers into the community. This leaves students with an insufficient number of class days and eliminates any sense of trust and continuity between young children and their educators. We aim to fix this issue by building a living quarter for the teacher on school grounds and providing a salary to support his/her living expenses. These improvements will ensure lengthier teacher involvement within the community.
 
 2) A Place to Learn, a Place to Play: Schoolhouse Refurbishment
          
The current kindergarten made of gray concrete walls and two adjoining desks does not provide a conducive atmosphere for 4-6 year old children to learn, play, and grow. We will revitalize the current classroom by expanding the size to accommodate 25 students, adding electricity, painting the walls a vibrant color to cover the grey concrete, planting a garden, and making a futból field. In so doing, the children will have the learning environment they need to grow into well-rounded individuals.  
 
3) Books, puzzles, and toys, oh my!: Educational Materials
                 
The kids are tired of reading the same disintegrating books over and over again. We will provide computers that have educational videos and games, along with new reading books, pens, paper, and arts and crafts supplies. By making learning fun, we aim to improve their literacy rates, basic mathematical concepts, and writing abilities. 
 
4) No more rumbling in my tummy: Nutrition
         
The intense poverty in San Antonio de Rioyos is manifested in the community’s lack of access to basic food.  The children come to school without having had breakfast. Although they have a break to go home for lunch, they often remain at school because their parents cannot afford to provide them with an afternoon meal. To shift the kids’ focus from their rumbling tummies to solving “1+1” in the classroom, FTDO will introduce a nutrition program that starts bright and early: we will give kids a healthy breakfast of local milk, bananas, and whole grain crackers.
 
 
 
YOUR IMPACT:   
         
Every donation, big or small, will go exclusively toward the revitalization of the kindergarten in San Antonio de Rioyos. 
 
By June 2014, all donations will be matched 5X by Fair Trade Social premiums provided by Fair Trade company Organic Alliance, Inc, so that we can continue the work that you start!
 
 
        
 
 
 
All of your support for this campaign does not only revitalize the community’s kindergarten, but also lays the foundation for our subsequent goal of creating a digital learning and recreation center, elementary, middle and high schools. These multi-phase projects make up La Esquina de la Educación. Together, we can build more than a kindergarten. We can build an entire movement toward quality education for the area.
Furthermore, if you have any questions, or would like to get involved, please do not hesitate to contact us! 
Patricia O’RourkeYasamin Soltanianzadeh

 
Who We Are: 
We here at the Fair Trade Development Organization (FTDO) are dedicated to improving lives in rural Fair Trade agricultural communities in Latin America. We are a non-profit organization that identifies opportunities to build a better future in remote communities in need of basic health care, schooling, and economic opportunity. After personally working with communities, we harness resources through crowd-funding, donors, partners, and the Fair Trade market to bring those projects to life. With a ‘boots-on-the-ground’ approach, FTDO works directly with communities to identify, plan, and execute social projects for the highest social return with the greatest level of efficiency. 

 Please visit us at our website.

story:
Yours Humanly is a 501(c)(3) non-profit charitable organization, devoted to bridging gaps between the fortunate and the not-so-fortunate children and giving them the opportunity to color their futures. Our primary goal is to enable the underprivileged children to achieve a better life through education.  We believe that in today's world just like food and shelter, education is a basic necessity.  Our vision is to work towards creating a world where all children, regardless of their age, gender, race, color, ethnicity, caste, religion, national origin, and physical, mental or financial ability, will have a fair chance at getting an education at a credible educational institution.

We are currently working in certain parts of India, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Cambodia, Philippines, and South Africa, and are looking to raise a minimum of $50,000 this holiday season, for the 2014 school year.  $15,000 of this money will be used to adopt a school in Cambodia and offer English and Computer education to the students; $15,000 will be used towards sending 50-75 underprivileged children to school in India and Nepal, paying for their tuition, uniforms and books;  $10,000 will be used towards sending 50 underprivileged children to school in Sri Lanka; and the remaining $10,000 will be used for a project in Philippines.

We are very passionate about what we do and are transparent about our projects.  Please visit our website www.yourshumanly.org for more information.

If you believe in our cause and want to be a part of an organization that is working towards education for all, kindly support our efforts with your generous donations.  It will be very much appreciated !  Donate today and give the gift of education this holiday season !

story:
Our characters have been working together for 8 years.  We started as characters for the Chesterton Wizard of Oz Festival and, over time, expanded our audience by appearing at numerous events such as The Indianapolis 500 Kids Festival, The Indiana State Fair, Oz-Stravaganza! (2009) in Chittenango, and many more.  We also donate our services to charitible organizations and children's hospitals.

In September of 2013, we were contracted as the Official Characters for Warner Bros. 75th Anniversary celebration of The Wizard of Oz in Hollywood, California. This appearance snagged us a spot on Entertainment Tonight and multiple media outlines (print, video, and web) including Yahoo! Movies and The Daily Mail UK.

Many costumed character groups simply show up and pose for photos, our group does much more than that!  We sing and dance, we emcee events - basically we strive to make our characters as much a part of an event as possible.  We love spending one-on-one time with attendees - chatting, playing games, whatever we can do to make the event as special as possible. 

This Campaign

This campaign is to help send us to Oz-Stravaganza in Chittenango, New York, this summer.  This event is held in the hometown of L. Frank Baum, the author of the Wizard of Oz, and celebrates all things Oz!  We last appeared at this event in 2009.  We had an awesome time and have wanted to return ever since; with this summer marking the 75th Anniversary of the film and the International Wizard of Oz Club holding their national convention in conjunction with this festival, there is no better time!  Unfortunately, the trip can be quite costly and if hard for us to cover.  The event organizers also love having us, but with everything they have on their plate, it is not always possible for them to provide the financial support we need.  We are asking that you consider contributing to our cause and helping us get to Chittenango so that we may provide the families, fans, and children with quality entertainment with a touch of magic!

What We Need & What You Get

A trip such as this has many expenses including:

  • Gas - Like with all trips, we need fuel for our vehicles and in today's economy it can be killer!
  • Hotels - Hotels are one of the more costly aspects of our trips.  While we bunk about 4 to a room, it is still rather costly, as we must worry about hotels not only at the event but also on the way to and from. 
  • Costume Maintenance - We typically do 5-10 events per year.  With all the moving, dancing, marching in parades, repeated packing and unpacking, and so on, our costumes take quite a good deal of wear and tear.  This requires periodic maintenance, cleaning, and, after so many years, replacement eventually.  Also, new makeup must be bought every so often. 
  • Misc. Expenses - Even "fictional" characters must eat.  We must also keep certain things on hand such as bottled water, first aid kit, etc.

As you look below, you will notice we have various sponsorship levels with varying incentives.  While you may give any amount from $1.00 and up, these levels provide you with several great great perks including:

  • Advertisement on Facebook page
  • Name/Business listed on our cast t-shirt
  • Autographed photos
  • Advertisement at the event
  • An appearance by the characters at your event/business
  • Much more

The Impact

Think of the joy you can help bring to countless children by helping send the characters to Oz-Stravaganza.  You should see their faces light up when they meet Dorothy and friends for the first time!  You are also helping the not-for-profit organization who runs the festival, by helping them bring more entertainment to the event with very little out-of-pocket expense.  The International Wizard of Oz Club will also benefit as the characters will be available for their national convention taking place in conjunction with Oz-Stravaganza!

Other Ways You Can Help

Financial donations are not the only way you can help.  You or your business may also provide assistance in one of the following ways:

  • In-kind donations of snacks, bottled, water, etc.
  • Business in the area may help to provide food and lodging.
  • Help spread the word of our campaign!
  • Vouchers, coupons, and discounts for our various expenses.

story:
Our Story

The primary goals of the organization are to free children from poverty and exploitation and free young people from the notion that they are powerless to affect positive change in the world. Through domestic empowerment programs and leadership training, Free The Children inspires young people to develop as socially conscious global citizens and become agents of change for their peers around the world.

The Impact

We are working to build a school in Ecuador. Free The Children works to dismantle the idea of simple aid, and truly empower communities to success by making them equal partners in the development process. This philosophy is at work within all of our projects in Ecuador. Community-building is a well-known practice for many indigenous regions in the Andes, including San Miguel. Deeply rooted in their culture, the population of San Miguel has practiced community-building for centuries under the concept of “mingas.” A minga is a community event through which all members contribute for the benefit of the community as a whole.

The people of San Miguel have been actively involved in mingas in working with Free The Children to build a school. It is through this process that the entire community decided where the new school should be built so everyone in San Miguel could access it. Community members volunteered through mingas to help make the adobe bricks for the structure, carry the construction materials and lay the foundation for the school.

What We Need & What You Get

We are currently building a school in Ecuador, and need to raise $8500 in order to start the school. We are very close to our goal, only 1000 dollars short.

story:
The Story

     Hello, my name is Ariel. Growing up I was surrounded by people of many cultures. As a child with unbridled curiosity, I was constantly seeking to learn about others of different cultures. I believe interacting with others different from myself can expand my point of view of the world. Unfortunately, my curiosity now has been limited to the boundaries of the U.S. Throughout my youth, I have had to provide for myself, which includes paying for my schooling. As a result, financial constraints have stifled my plans to travel. Fortunately, a friend of mine recently told me about a wonderful program where I would be able to travel, while serving others along the way. The program is called Interexchange, which provides an outlet for people such as myself to explore the world and partake in a life-changing international experience. Thus, fostering my cultural and social understanding of those different from myself. For one year I will be a mentor to and teach children from indigent families English.

    Nevertheless, I will not be the only individual reaping the benefits from this program. The children I will be working with will also gain an opportunity to learn about someone different from themselves. It is my hope that we will both be able to teach and learn from each other.

    With your help I will finally be able to live out my dreams and hopefully impact the lives of children.


The Impact

    I have been blessed to receive assistance, guidance and wisdom from many influential people in my life. I believe it’s my obligation to extend the same compassion and encouragement to someone less fortunate. Just think of how many children do not have access to good education and lack positive role models in their lives. By donating what you can, you are not only helping me, but you become part of a bigger picture. You’re helping a child grow into a future contributing member of society. Help me help them I really want to be apart of the change don't you? Let’s make a change together!


What We Need & What You Get

    Currently, I am working two jobs to try and come up with the remainder of the amount I will need. I have already depleted my savings and am working hard to fill this gap.  However, I am still short on my goal. I will need a total of $4,000. This amount will cover:

  • A round trip ticket to my destination (France) ≈ $1,300 USD
  • Required program laptop (I will be using this for lesson plans) ≈ $500 USD
  • Teaching materials (activity books, grade books, learning CD/ROMs, dry erase boards, etc.) ≈ $500 USD
  • School program fee ≈ $498 USD
  • Health Insurance fee for the year ≈ $500 USD
  • Visa & Visa tax ≈ $607 USD


     For those who contribute and leave their contact information, I will personally send you a thank you card and a special gift.

Other Ways You Can Help

    Please broadcast this to colleagues, classmates, family members, friends via social media and word of mouth! I would greatly appreciate all of your help!

 

GOD BLESS and THANK YOU

story:
I’m Louis Cabrera, a youth program manager of an after-school program for the middle school population at IS 52M provided by Inwood Community Services, inc. I’ve worked in the non-profit youth service field for a little over 15 years, and during my tenure I developed a philosophy of youth-led adult-guided program development.  One simultaneously maximizes programmatic success and builds youth self-esteem/social-emotional development when the perspectives and voices of young people are incorporated into programmatic design.

Something I’ve noticed is the need for after-programing for HS student sin the Inwood Community. As my middle-school program participants age out, they keep coming back to “volunteer”. Every year the number of youth who came back grew. This academic school year this number swelled to the point where we could no longer accommodate them in our current program structure.

I met with all of them and came up with a program design that meets their needs, and here I am asking for your help in bringing THEIR PROGRAM to fruition.

So in response to great demand, Inwood Community Services is starting a new After School Program for up to 30 High School students.

We need to raise at least $3,000 to get a basic and skeletal program off the ground and $20,000 to fully fund a four day a week program with teachers, regents test prep, leadership development and recreation from 4pm-6pm through June 2014.

Thank you in advance for supporting our cause!

Founding Sponsor: $1,000 & Over

Diamond Sponsor: $500 - $999

Platinum Sponsor: $250 - $499

Silver Sponsor: $100 - $249

Sponsor: $50 - $99

Friend: $1 - $49

story:
Four million children and adolescents in this country suffer from a serious mental disorder that causes significant functional impairments at home, at school and with peers. Of children ages 9 to 17, 21 percent have a diagnosable mental or addictive disorder that causes at least minimal impairment.

Half of all lifetime cases of mental disorders begin by age 14. Despite effective treatments, there are long delays, sometimes decades, between the first onset of symptoms and when people seek and receive treatment. An untreated mental disorder can lead to a more severe, more difficult to treat illness and to the development of co-occurring mental illnesses.  Social stigma associated with mental illness pervades all communities and is another barrier for families in need of help with their children to overcome.

Suicide is the third leading cause of death in youth ages 15 to 24. More teenagers and young adults die from suicide than from cancer, heart disease, AIDS, birth defects, stroke, pneumonia, influenza and chronic lung disease combined.Over 90 percent of children and adolescents who commit suicide have a mental disorder. States spend nearly $1 billion annually on medical costs associated with completed suicides and suicide attempts by youth up to 20 years of age.Idaho is currently ranked in the top five states for rate of suicide per capita.

In any given year, only 20 percent of children with mental disorders are identified and receive mental health services.  Research shows that early identification and intervention can minimize the long-term disability of mental disorders. Early and effective mental health treatment can prevent a significant proportion of delinquent and violent youth from future violence and crime. It also enables children and adolescents to succeed in school, to develop socially and to fully experience the developmental opportunities of childhood.

The Idaho Federation of Families for Children’s Mental Health would like to start a Video Blog highlighting current trends in Children’s Mental Health.  These Blogs would highlight different aspects of Children’s Mental Health, including early identification and diagnosis, early intervention treatment, family support, education and advocacy groups, suicide prevention, pertinent laws and anti-stigma.

Through interviews with current Children’s Mental Health leaders and presentations by acknowledged authorities this blog would be a clearinghouse for families seeking assistance, support and knowledge when a loved one is diagnosed with a mental disability without fear of anticipated social consequences resulting from the stigma associated with mental illness.

These presentations will be made available on the internet and on DVD upon request.

The funds collected would be used to upgrade some obsolete equipment which would augment the current donated equipment and to provide some travel expenses for presenters, as well as produce the DVDs.

Any amount will help, even if you cannot give please let people know about the resource and that a mental health issue is not a reason to feel shame.



Original art work by Sheridan Smede

presentations will be made available on the internet and on DVD upon request.The funds collected would be used to upgrade some obsolete equipment which would augment the current donated equipment and to provide some travel expenses for presenters, as well as produce the DVDs.
Any
amount will help, even if you cannot give please let people know about the
resource and that a mental health issue is not a reason to feel shame.




Original art work by Sheridan Smede

story:
For the past 13+ years Jay Randle has offered both adults and children the opportunity to learn to ride horses and compete in the sport of endurance riding at Splendacrest Stables.  Many of the students who learned to ride at Splendacrest have gone on to represent Australia in international competition, and many more have fulfilled their horsey dreams and goals in other ways.

Due to a grave illness in the family, the property on which Splendacrest operates must be sold, leaving Jay without a home or place to continue her work with these students.

Splendacrest needs a home!  The ideal solution would be to fund the purchase of the current property, enabling the continued use of the facilities and infrastructure that has been built up over the years.  However current drought conditions have seen all Jays savings plowed into the care of her precious horses, with very little emergency funds left available to secure the future of Splendacrest.

She needs your help. 

The current property consists of 40 acres of black soil, with a good underground water supply, a 100+ year old barn, and an older style timber home.  The Splendacrest Stables riding school is home to four lovely aged semi-retired horses in their forever home, and three other quiet reliable horses who love their jobs of teaching youngsters from the age of 4 years to ride.

In addition, Jay operates an endurance riding program for older children and adults who have progressed through the riding school.  This program has enabled hundreds of students to learn about and enjoy long distance riding, with the emphasis on the health and welfare of the horse at all times.

The horses used in the endurance training program are well-loved members of the Splendacrest family.  The many young (and not-so-young) riders know that these horses will give them a wonderful experience, and will bring them home safely. 

By helping Jay in this fund-raising quest, YOU will also be able to participate in the Splendacrest experience!  There are several levels of funding "perks" on offer, including private lessons, Splendacrest merchandise, training for your endurance or Arabian racing horse, and even joining the Splendacrest team at an endurance ride!

All funds raised through this program will go towards purchasing a home for Splendacrest.  The primary goal would be to purchase the current property, however if that is not possible, all funds will be used to find an alternative home for Splendacrest.

Every penny counts!  Jay has an impeccable worldwide reputation, and a strong desire to see her students grow in knowledge and ability.  Now it is time to help her dreams be realised.  Please help to find a home for Splendacrest.

Although your generous donation will be highly treasured, you can also help by spreading the word among your friends about the need for this program to succeed.  Please share this fund-raising campaign with your friends and help to find a home for Splendacrest.

Thank you for your consideration of this vital program.

story:
A Week of Putting Ourselves in Their Shoes

UVM FeelGooders have joined the international youth movement to end the most critical global issue of this century: world hunger. Through this non-profit organization, your fellow students have donated over $200,000 to The Hunger Project, truly making a difference in the fight to end this devastating issue. Learning about the issues prevalent in the countries we are helping, we decided it was time to try to really understand the injustices these people deal with everyday. Although it will be tricky to know exactly what it feels like to live in extreme poverty, this week is dedicated to immerse ourselves in the lifestyles of those we are helping and informing others of the seriousness of this crisis. Each student participating in the week will set his or her own goal to raise money to continue to support the Hunger Project.  Our goal as a chapter is to raise $4,000 for The Hunger Project through this endeavor. By sponsoring this week, you have realized the urgency of this problem and the possibility of putting an end to it.


November 11-18, 2013: The Plan 

Monday- We dedicate this day to Uganda, a country where the majority of the people live on just $1 a day.  We will attempt to live on just one dollar for this entire day.  

Tuesday- We dedicate this day to Mozambique, a country where 56% of the population (23 million) are illiterate. No technology of any kind will be used unless work must be absolutely finished on a computer. No cell phones, no iPods, minimal light usage and other technological conveniences such as microwaves, teapots, etc.  

Wednesday- We dedicate this day to India a country that has prominent gender inequalities. We will do a "day of silence" to portray the need for strong female voices in India. We will wear T-Shirts that explain why we are not speaking.  These t-shirts will also have facts about gender inequality on them in an effort to spread awareness of this injustice. 

Thursday- We dedicate this day to Malawi, a country with one of the highest rates of H.I.V/AIDS. For this day, we will have free HIV testing, give out informational packets, and give blood.  

Sunday- We dedicate this day to celebrating all of the unique and awesome customs and values of the countries we are supporting.  We will have a potluck dinner where each person will bring in a dish from one of the countries the Hunger Project works in.  With their dish, each person should prepare to share one unique tradition from the country. After dinner, we will have a discussion based around how these customs and values are degraded when there is poverty and injustice.

story:
Short Summary

Hey there, I need your help! I'm hoping to travel with the charity Performers Without Borders (http://performerswithoutborders.org.uk) to Nicaragua for three months (10 January to 10 April 2013). PWB teaches performing arts to vunerable children in countries of high child poverty.

I am strong proponent of social circus. I completed PWB's 2007/8 tour in India and two tours in Thailand (2009 and 2010) with a similar charity called Spark Circus. I think teaching underprivileged children circus skills is a great way to encourage them to play for the sake of playing while also giving them attention and reminding them that anything's possible. Furthermore it helps develop an individual's learning and teamworking skills while fostering creativity and self confidence.

For the previous tours I've been on I have bought my own flight and covered the majority of my own expenses. However, this year I cannot afford to do so, but I still desperately want to go and teach circus in Nicaragua. Please can you help me raise the money? 

What I Need

I will need $1300 for my flight and $1,600 to cover all my food, accommodation and transport costs whilst in the country. Then any other money I make will go straight to PWB to buy equipment to leave with the children and other important things for the project to take place.

Other Ways You Can Help

I'd greatly appreciate it if you'd share this page with anyone you think might be interested.

Cheers,

Bags

xx

Other Information

The United Nations, Convention on the Rights of the Child, Article 31 recognises: “the right of the child to rest and leisure, to engage in play and recreational activities appropriate to the age of the child and to participate freely in cultural life and the arts.”

From Reg Bolton's PHD Thesis “Why Circus Works”: “It is gratifying that an activity which is so strongly recognised as fun, should also present developmental, intellectual and physical challenges, encourage social behaviour more creative and co-operative than competitive, and which has as its end product, an act of donation – of generosity.”

From “Our Vision” on the PWB website: “Performers Without Borders (PWB) works towards giving vulnerable children the opportunity to explore their potential. We understand that, through teaching performance skills an individual’s learning, creativity and team working skills are developed. Further, it helps to build confidence, develop empowerment and overcome social barriers. PWB’s methodology of following the tradition of travelling show, and the principle of fostering long-term relationships, is ideal in not only engaging children, but also ensuring community trust in the project.”

story:
Short Summary

For the past year and a half I have been working on a federally funded project as Community Interventions Coordinator. In my role, I have engaged, trained, and supported a network of 10 organizations across the city of Chicago who were implementing 4 community level interventions aimed at creating healthier environments in their neighborhoods. The intervention focus areas were Healthy Schools, Healthy Corner Stores, Breastfeeding Support, and Neighborhood Walkability. Our funding period has come to an end, and I am left contemplating my next steps.

As many of you know I am extremely passionate about supporting women and their families in making holistic and informed decisions around the physical, mental and emotional health of their families- especially during pregnancy, as they prepare for birth, and during breastfeeding.

The next logical step for me on my journey is to position myself to better support women in my community. I am interested in becoming a Certified Lactation Counselor (CLC).

Over the past two years, I have already provided peer to peer breastfeeding support to many women. I would like to increase my knowledge base as well as my capacity to ensure that I am providing the most accurate, up to date, and relevant information and resources to the women I serve.


Many women that I have interacted with who have not met their initial breastfeeding goals, have stated that some of the main barriers they experienced were: 

  • lack of access to support after leaving the hospital
  • lack of support in their home, work, and personal life
  • and not knowing that the challenges they were experiencing were common and could've been overcome if they had the aforementioned support

Upon becoming a CLC some of my goals are to:

  • offer breastfeeding 101 classes for women and their families,
  • facilitate breastfeeding support groups
  • create an online space for breastfeeding support
  • conduct one on one breastfeeding support sessions for moms post partum

My target demographic will women who are underserved by lactation support including but not limited to Black and Brown moms, teens, unemployed, un/under insured, etc.

What I Need

I am looking to raise $900 to use towards costs associate with a CLC training course.

The Healthy Children Project will be conducting a training in the Chicagoland area in the middle of October, and I need your HELP with the following: 

$725.00- Tuition

$55.00- Required Books

$120- Additional Books and materials to support my journey

If I am unable to raise the funds to attend the training, the money will be spent on purchasing books, and other materials that will assist me in increasing my knowledge, and I will seek out other opportunities for professional development in the field.

Depending on how close I get, I may be able to supplement the remainder and register for the course the next time they are in the area.

If I raise extra funds, the excess will be used towards planting seeds to implement one or more of the above goals.

 

The Impact

The benefits of breastfeeding are immense. And there is a need in our communities for an increase in lactation professionals, especially those who can relate to women from underserved and traditionally marginalized demographics in a way that people outside of our communities can not. There is a stigma that Black women do not breastfeed. I want to challenge that stereotype by being a walking, talking, breastfeeding example and a source of support and information for mothers who are interested in breastfeeding, breastfeeding, or unsure about whether or not breastfeeding is the right choice for their family.

It is not my intention to judge or down women for not choosing to breastfeed. In fact, I wish to present information in as clear, relatable, and concise way to help moms feel comfortable and confident with their infant feeding decisions.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to support financially, please consider the following:

  • get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. in your social and personal networks.
  • offer prayers, positive thoughts, and well wishes to me on my journey

 

Peace and Blessings- Love and Light

story:
Nairobi Developer School is a three month program for programmers to learn and improve their skills!

A Dev School in Nairobi!

My name is Martha Chumo, though I make noise online as "Njeri Chelimo". :) I'm a 19 year old developer from Nairobi, Kenya. About two months ago, I ran this campaign on Indiegogo requesting people to help me attend Hacker School in New York. I was really excited that I got into Hacker School, and got the funds to go and become a better programmer...but unfortunately, I am not attending Hacker School because I am not eligible for a US tourist visa.

Help women get ahead in Tech! :)

Nairobi Developer School will paricularly address the great gender inbalance in the technology by encouranging women to participate in the program, and offer financial support to those who need it. We will invite women and other minority groups in tech to apply and the program allows them to thrive. Please reach out to us in the links below to help us achieve this! :)

Update - Why am I ineligible for a tourist visa? I'm an unmarried 19 year old woman with no kids.

A number of people have emailed me enquiring about my ineligibility, so I thought I could explain here. I applied for a tourist visa for the first time and got a really fast denial. The consular said, "You are in your gap year... I'm sorry". A gap year is the time in between high school and university. I am to start college in September. My persistent self and supporters went ahead to reapply for the same visa, believing I was eligible. I got support letters from Hacker School, AdaCamp SF (I was to be a participant), GNOME Outreach Program for Women, Codecademy community manager, Madison Ruby, my mentor from the Apache Deltacloud Project, and my partners in Kenya. During my second visa interview, I got a really nice consular who explained that the problem is not with support documentation or funds - it was with me. The consular said, and I quote, "You need social ties to Kenya. And now that you're an adult - I'm 19 - your parents do not count". This basically translates to I'm ineligible because I am an  unmarried 19 year old with no kids, not in her 3rd year of University, and has not worked for a company or the government for many years. I need these "social ties" to tie me to Kenya. I'm certain my friends do not count as "social ties". ;)

We all deserve a chance to be better programmers!

I'm ineligible to go to New York for Hacker School, but I am not ineligible to learn and become a better programmer! So I am starting a Dev School in Nairobi to give myself and numerous young East Africans a chance to learn, improve their programming skills, and build awesome technology for Africa. I am really excited about this because I still get to "become a better programmer" this summer while teaching and helping others also.

The Impact - Help create more success stories!

You can watch Shiko's Story here. There are so many young Kenyans with degrees who are misplaced in the job market or simply cannot find decent jobs. There are even more young potential entrepreneurs willing to learn and/or improve their skills. Through the Nairobi Dev School, these young people will get a chance to improve their skills or learn new skills while building job-creating technology. In our plans most will end up employing themselves while creating employment for others.

Shiko - How I got into code...

"I studied biochemistry in  university. I have worked in sales and marketing, project management and other random paper pushing jobs which had little or nothing to do with tech. When Martha first introduced me to programming, I was skeptical because I thought programming was all binary code which is something i was not remotely interested in.  She gave me books on html and css. Out of curiosity i read them. And that was it, I was sucked in for life! I love web design and self learning is so mind blowing.I mean i was like a kid with a new toy. I could wake up at four in the morning to do a simple mock up, play with different backgrounds and fonts and i get sooo happy. Btw i have only been learning for a month now as I write this. I quit my job two weeks ago to become a full time learner of code. My first project is my personal site, I am working on the mock up on photoshop. I also plan to build a platform for learning and teaching on ruby on rails with Martha. Nothing else matters to me at this point other than learning web design ,development and other "stuff" that will make me successful in life. Thanks to Martha and the Nairobi Dev School there is hope for life learners and tech visionaries like me!"

What is the money for?

The money we raise in this campaign will be used to set up the Dev School and run it for almost year! I have a budget of about $5000 a month. The money will be used for:

  • Renting out a space for the school.

  • Fast-speed internet connection.

  • Electricity for the school.

  • Buying chairs and desks and any other furniture in the beginning.

  • Buying laptops for participants.

  • Financial support to participants.  

  • Snacks during the program.

  • Volunteer stipends.

 

These are the basics things needed to learn, but unfortunately, are not accessible to most (almost all!) of Africans. So providing them at the school is the only way to ensure the school is an equal opportunity for all! :)

Nairobi Dev School will be a space for learners to come in and program awesome stuff using online tools. There will be optional Ruby on Rails classes (taught by me), and the rest will be self-learning and collaborative learning!

I need the funds to start it because the school will be free. Anyone who applies will attend the school for 3 months for free. This is the same experience I was going to get at Hacker school, and I want others to enjoy the same!

The funds will be used to get space, an Internet connection, electricity and any suppport services for the Dev School. I already raised more than $5000 from my previous campaign. I am using this to start out Nairobi Dev School, as I look for more funds to keep it runnning.

How else can I help?

  • Help me make some noise about the campaign. Share it with all your networks, and companies you think will be interested in supporting this course! You can use the Indiegogo share tools above.

  • Are you in Nairobi? Awesome! Connect with me (martha.c.chumo@gmail.com), and join the team planning the Dev School! We currently work from the iHub. Feel free to come visit and share your thoughts on Nairobi Dev School.

  • Feeling inspired? Move to Nairobi and help us set up! :D Nairobi is really cheap to live, and has awesome weather. Plus, you get to work with a motivated team on a great cause! Email or tweet me, and let's discuss this possibility! :D

  • Email me ideas you have about the school! How can I make the impact greater? How can we reach more programmers in East Africa? Want to start a Dev School in Kampala, Uganda? Tell us about it! We could work together! :)

  • You or your company can sponsor any of the things we need for the school. You can sponsor the space, internet connection, electricity, desks, chairs, laptops for students who are unable to acquire one, or any support service!

  • Are you a dev? Volunteer to mentor some of Nairobi Dev School attendees!

I am are really excited about creating this opportunity in Nairobi! I hope you can support me in enabling more people become better programmers.

I'm ineligible to go to New York for Hacker School, but I am not ineligible to learn and become a better programmer! So I am starting a Dev School in Nairobi to give myself and numerous young East Africans a chance to learn, improve their programming skills, and build awesome technology for Africa. I am really excited about this because I still get to "become a better programmer" this summer while teaching and helping others also.
The Impact - Help create more success stories!
You can watch Shiko's Story here. There are so many young Kenyans with degrees who are misplaced in the job market or simply cannot find decent jobs. There are even more young potential entrepreneurs willing to learn and/or improve their skills. Through the Nairobi Dev School, these young people will get a chance to improve their skills or learn new skills while building job-creating technology. In our plans most will end up employing themselves while creating employment for others.
Shiko - How I got into code...
"I studied biochemistry in  university. I have worked in sales and marketing, project management and other random paper pushing jobs which had little or nothing to do with tech. When Martha first introduced me to programming, I was skeptical because I thought programming was all binary code which is something i was not remotely interested in.  She gave me books on html and css. Out of curiosity i read them. And that was it, I was sucked in for life! I love web design and self learning is so mind blowing.I mean i was like a kid with a new toy. I could wake up at four in the morning to do a simple mock up, play with different backgrounds and fonts and i get sooo happy. Btw i have only been learning for a month now as I write this. I quit my job two weeks ago to become a full time learner of code. My first project is my personal site, I am working on the mock up on photoshop. I also plan to build a platform for learning and teaching on ruby on rails with Martha. Nothing else matters to me at this point other than learning web design ,development and other "stuff" that will make me successful in life. Thanks to Martha and the Nairobi Dev School there is hope for life learners and tech visionaries like me!"
 What is the money for?
The money we raise in this campaign will be used to set up the Dev School and run it for almost year! I have a budget of about $5000 a month. The money will be used for:


Renting out a space for the school.


Fast-speed internet connection.


Electricity for the school.


Buying chairs and desks and any other furniture in the beginning.


Buying laptops for participants.


Financial support to participants.  


Snacks during the program.

Volunteer stipends.
 
These are the basics things needed to learn, but unfortunately, are not accessible to most (almost all!) of Africans. So providing them at the school is the only way to ensure the school is an equal opportunity for all! :)
Nairobi Dev School will be a space for learners to come in and program awesome stuff using online tools. There will be optional Ruby on Rails classes (taught by me), and the rest will be self-learning and collaborative learning!
I need the funds to start it because the school will be free. Anyone who applies will attend the school for 3 months for free. This is the same experience I was going to get at Hacker school, and I want others to enjoy the same!
The funds will be used to get space, an Internet connection, electricity and any suppport services for the Dev School. I already raised more than $5000 from my previous campaign. I am using this to start out Nairobi Dev School, as I look for more funds to keep it runnning.
